analyzed: śrīḥ
translated: Śrī.

analyzed: śrī hariḥ jayati
translated: Śrī Hari is victorious.

analyzed: śrīmate rāmānujāya namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the illustrious Rāmānuja.
In the three Siddhis approved by the great teacher, the illustrious sage Yāmuna, the Siddhi of Consciousness.
Accompanied by a commentary named Siddhañjana.

analyzed: ekam eva advitīyam tat brahma iti upaniṣad vacaḥ
translated: The Upaniṣad says, That Brahman is one without a second.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ nyasya sadbhāvam nanu tat pratiṣedhati
translated: Does it not deny the existence of anything other than Brahman?

original: vyākhyā īṣṭe viśvasya nityaṃ vyapagatatulanāyogyavastvantaro yo vidye yasyādhigatyai vidurupaniṣado dve parāṃ cāparāṃ ca /
analyzed: vyākhyā īṣṭe viśvasya nityam vyapagata tulanā yogya vastu antaraḥ yaḥ vidye yasya adhigatyai viduḥ upaniṣadaḥ dve parām ca aparām ca
translated: The one who is always desired to be the expounder of the universe, whose knowledge is the Upaniṣads, the higher and the lower, for the attainment of which,

original: yo viśvasvāntavāsī prathayati ca dhiyaṃ tasya tasyānurūpāṃ devaḥ śrīmān sa mahyaṃ pradiśatu dayayā dhīvikāsaṃ samantāt // //
analyzed: yaḥ viśva sva anta vāsī prathayati ca dhiyam tasya tasya anurūpām devaḥ śrīmān sa mahyam pradiśatu dayayā dhī vikāsam samantāt
translated: May that glorious god, who resides in the heart of the universe and spreads the mind in accordance with each one, bestow on me, with compassion, the unfolding of the mind in every way.

analyzed: yāmuna āśaya vijñam tam dhyātvā lakṣmaṇa yoginam
translated: Having meditated on that Lakshmana yogi, who is known to have the abode of Yāmuna,

analyzed: yāmuna ārya kṛtim saṃvid siddhim vyākaravāṇi aham
translated: I shall explain the Siddhi of Consciousness, the work of the noble Yāmuna.

analyzed: pramāṇa phala rūpāyāḥ saṃvidaḥ prameya tattva vyavasthāpikāyāḥ sva rūpa ādi viśodhyate saṃvid tiddhau
translated: In this Siddhi of Consciousness, which is the means of valid knowledge and its result, and which establishes the true nature of the object of knowledge, its nature and so on are examined.

analyzed: iyam ādimā siddhi traye śloka vārtika chloka mālikā rūpā
translated: This is the first of the three Siddhis, in the form of a verse commentary and a garland of verses.

analyzed: tantra vārtika vat ca ātma īśvara siddhī  atra ca upakrama madhya avasāneṣu bhūyān grantha bhāgaḥ luptaḥ
translated: And like the Tantravartika, it is for the attainment of the Self and God.🔽And here, a large part of the text is lost in the beginning, middle, and end.

original: upalabhyamānasaṃvitsiddhibhāge ca bahulamadvaitimatanirāso dṛśyate /🔽advaitino hisadeva somyedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīyamiti kāraṇībhūtasya sacchabditasya
analyzed: upalabhyamāna saṃvid siddhi bhāge ca bahulam advaiti mata nirāsaḥ dṛśyate  advaitinaḥ hi sat eva somya idam agre āsīt ekam eva advitīyam iti kāraṇībhūtasya sat śabditasya
translated: And in the part that is available, the attainment of consciousness, a lot of refutation of the Advaita view is seen.🔽For the Advaitins say that This world, my dear, existed in the beginning as the One without a second.

analyzed: para brahmaṇaḥ dvitīya tva śravaṇāt satyam jñānam anantam brahma iti jñāna mātra tva śravaṇāt ca
translated: Hearing the non-duality of the supreme Brahman called Sat, which is the cause, and hearing that it is Truth, Knowledge, and Infinity, which is the statement of Brahman being mere knowledge,

analyzed: sajātīya vijātīya svagata bheda sāmānya śūnyam brahma eva cit mātram sat paramārthaḥ
translated: they declare that Brahman alone, which is pure consciousness, is the ultimate reality, devoid of internal and external distinctions and general distinctions.

analyzed: anyat sarvam tatra eva avidyayā parikalpitam mithyā bhūtam iti āmananti
translated: They say that everything else is superimposed on it by ignorance and is false.

analyzed: tatra advitīya śruteḥ tad abhimata artha pratipādaka tva asambhavam varṇayitum ādau tad matam anuvadati ekam eva iti
translated: To describe the impossibility of conveying their intended meaning due to the non-dualistic statement, he first repeats their view, saying One alone.

analyzed: yad tadoḥ nitya saṃbandhāt pūrva ardhe yadi ti anuṣajyate
translated: If is understood in the first part due to the eternal connection of yat and tat.

analyzed: yat upaniṣad vacaḥ
translated: That which is the statement of the Upanishads.

analyzed: tat iti anvayaḥ
translated: That which is the statement of the Upaniṣads.🔽The word that is to be supplied.

original: yadvā uttarārdhe tacchadbaḥ prasiddhaparāmarśī na tu yacchabdanirdiṣṭapratinirdeśarūpaḥ /
analyzed: yat vā uttara ardhe tad chadbaḥ prasiddha parāmarśī na tu yad śabda nirdiṣṭa pratinirdeśa rūpaḥ
translated: Or, in the latter part, the word that refers to what is well-known, but is not a substitute indicated by the word that.

analyzed: tat brahma iti atra sat brahma iti pāṭhaḥ saṃbhāvyate
translated: In that Brahman, the reading sat-brahman is possible.

analyzed: brahma vāci sat pada viśeṣaṇam advitīya padam brahmaṇaḥ nyasya asattva param iti pūrvapakṣiṇām āśayaḥ
translated: The intention of the opponents is that the word advitīya (without a second), which is a qualifier of the word sat (being) denoting Brahman, means that nothing else exists.

analyzed: atre brūmaḥ dvitīya uktau samāsaḥ kaḥ vivakṣitaḥ
translated: Here we say: In the statement without a second, which type of compound is intended?

analyzed: kim svid tatpuruṣaḥ kim vā bahuvrīhiḥ atha ucyatām
translated: Is it a tatpuruṣa compound or a bahuvrīhi compound? Let it be stated.

analyzed: tam imam dūṣayitum advitīya pade vṛttim vikalpayati siddhāntī atra iti
translated: In order to refute this, the proponent of the conclusion considers the function of the word advitīya (without a second): Here, he says.

analyzed: a dvitīya uktau a dvitīya pade
translated: In the statement without a second, in the word advitīya.

analyzed: athavā kim bahuvrīhiḥ iti anvayaḥ
translated: Or else, the construction is: Is it a bahuvrīhi compound?

analyzed: pūrvasmin uttaraḥ tāvat prādhānyena vivakṣyate
translated: In the former, the latter is first intended as primary.

analyzed: padārthaḥ tatra tat brahma tatas nyat sadṛśam tu vā
translated: The meaning of the word is that Brahman, which is similar to that or opposed to it.

analyzed: tat viruddham atho vā syāt triṣu api anyat na bādhate
translated: In all three, nothing else is contradicted.

original: anyatve sadṛśatve vā dvitīyaṃ sidhyati dhruvam // //
analyzed: anya tve sadṛśa tve vā dvitīyam sidhyati dhruvam
translated: If it is different or similar, the second is certainly established.

original: advitīyapadasya tatpuruṣavṛttatve na dvitīyasya bādha ityāhapūrvasmin ityādinā ślokacatuṣṭayena /🔽tatpuruṣa iti prathamakalpe tāvaduttarapadārthaḥ prādhānyena vivakṣyate /🔽uttarapadārthapradhānatvāttatpuruṣasyetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: advitīya padasya tatpuruṣa vṛtta tve na dvitīyasya bādhaḥ iti āha pūrvasmin ityādinā śloka catuṣṭayena  tatpuruṣaḥ iti prathama kalpe tāvat uttara padārthaḥ prādhānyena vivakṣyate  uttara padārtha pradhāna tvāt tatpuruṣasya iti arthaḥ
translated: In the case of the compound 'advitīya' (non-dual), there is no contradiction of a second, he says in the four verses beginning with 'pūrvasmin' (in the former).🔽In the first alternative, the meaning of the latter word is expressed as primary in the tatpuruṣa compound.🔽The meaning is: because the tatpuruṣa compound has the meaning of the latter word as primary.

analyzed: tatra iti
translated: There, in the tatpuruṣa compound, the meaning of the former word is superimposed.

analyzed: na dvitīyam a dvitīyam
translated: There is no second, non-dual.

original: nañtatpuruṣe cāropitatvasya pūrvapadārthatvaṃ tasya cottarapadārthaviśeṣaṇatvamiṣyate śābdikaiḥ /
analyzed: nañ tatpuruṣe ca āropita tvasya pūrva padārtha tvam tasya ca uttara padārtha viśeṣaṇa tvam iṣyate śābdikaiḥ
translated: And in the tatpuruṣa compound with the negative particle, the meaning of the former word is superimposed, and that is considered to be the qualifier of the meaning of the latter word by the grammarians.

analyzed: āropaḥ ca sadṛśa ādau
translated: And superimposition is in what is similar and so on.

analyzed: tad phalita kathanam tad anya ādi arthe naṃ iti
translated: The result of that is stated: the negative particle has a different meaning.

original: nañivayuktamanyasadṛśādhikaraṇe tathā hyarthagatiriti ca śābdikānāṃ paribhāṣā /
analyzed: nañ iva yuktam anya sadṛśa adhikaraṇe tathā hi artha gatiḥ iti ca śābdikānām paribhāṣā
translated: The grammarians have the convention that the negative particle is used in the same way as in the case of what is similar to another, because in that way the meaning is understood.

original: tathā cādvitīyapadenāropitadvitīyatvavadbrahmeti bodhe tatra dvitīyānyatvasya dvitīyasadṛśatvasya dvitīyaviruddhatvasya vā pratītiḥ phalati
analyzed: tathā ca advitīya padena āropita dvitīya tva vat brahma iti bodhe tatra dvitīya anya tvasya dvitīya sadṛśa tvasya dvitīya viruddha tvasya vā pratītiḥ phalati
translated: And thus, when the word 'advitīya' (non-dual) conveys the understanding that Brahman is like what is superimposed as a second, the cognition of being different from a second, being similar to a second, or being contradictory to a second results.

analyzed: artha traye pi brahma bhinnasya dvitīya padārthasya na bādhaḥ
translated: In all three meanings, there is no contradiction of the meaning of the word 'second' which is different from Brahman.

original: dvitīyapratiyogikasya bhedasya sādṛśyasya vā pratibodhane pratiyogitayā dvitīyasiddherniṣpratyūhatvāditi bhāvaḥ // // //
analyzed: dvitīya pratiyogikasya bhedasya sādṛśyasya vā pratibodhane pratiyogitayā dvitīya siddheḥ niṣpratyūha tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that when the difference or similarity of the second is brought to awareness, the establishment of the second as the counter-correlate is unobstructed.

original: viruddhatve dvitīyena tṛtīyaṃ prathamaṃ tu vā /
analyzed: viruddha tve dvitīyena tṛtīyam prathamam tu vā
translated: In contradiction, the third or the first is by the second.

analyzed: brahma prāpnoti yasmāt tat dvitīyena virudhyate  /
translated: Brahman is attained because it is contradicted by the second.

original: nanvevamapi dvitīyaviruddhatve brahmaṇo bodhite kathaṃ na dvitīyasya bādha ityatrāhaviruddhatvaiti /
analyzed: nanu evam api dvitīya viruddha tve brahmaṇaḥ bodhite katham na dvitīyasya bādhaḥ iti atra āha viruddha tva iti
translated: Even so, when the contradiction of Brahman by the second is brought to awareness, how is there no contradiction of the second? To this he says: By contradiction, etc.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ dvitīya tvam atra dvitva saṅkhyā pūraka tva rūpam
translated: The idea is this: Here, secondness has the nature of fulfilling the number two.

analyzed: dvitīya viruddha tvam ca dvitīya tva viruddha dharmavat tvāt
translated: And contradiction by the second is due to having a property that is contradictory to secondness.

original: sa ca dharmaḥ prathamatvaṃ niyamataḥ tṛtīyatvādi vā /
analyzed: sa ca dharmaḥ prathama tvam niyamataḥ tṛtīya tva ādi vā
translated: And that property is necessarily firstness or thirdness, etc.

analyzed: na etāvatā dvitīyasya kasyacid bādhaḥ iti
translated: By this much, there is no contradiction of any second.

analyzed: atas sa prathamāḥ sarve tṛtīya ādi artha rāśayaḥ
translated: Therefore, all the groups of third and other meanings, along with the first,

analyzed: dvitīyena tathā spṛṣṭvā svasthāḥ tiṣṭhanti abādhitāḥ
translated: are touched by the second in that way and remain unaffected, uncontradicted.

analyzed: tat āha atas iti
translated: He says that: Therefore, etc.

analyzed: dvitīyena dvi tva saṅkhyā pūrakeṇa
translated: By the second, which fulfills the number two.

analyzed: tathā spṛṣṭvā virodha saṃbandhena sambadhya
translated: Similarly, having touched, it is connected by the relation of contradiction.

analyzed: svasthāḥ sva sva pramāṇa adhīna siddhikāḥ santaḥ
translated: Being in their own natural state, they exist, being established by their own means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: advitīya uktyā ābādhitāḥ prathama tṛtīya ādi artha rāśayaḥ vartante eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the first, third, and other groups of objects, which are not contradicted by the statement of non-duality, exist.

analyzed: spṛṣṭāḥ iti pāṭhaḥ saṃbhāvyate  /
translated: The reading spṛṣṭāḥ is possible.

analyzed: nanu nam brahmaṇaḥ nyasya sarvasya eva niṣedhakam
translated: But the negative particle negates everything other than Brahman.

analyzed: dvitīya grahaṇam yasmāt sarvasya vā upalakṣaṇam  atra śaṅkate nanu nañ iti
translated: The use of the word second is a metonym for everything.🔽Here the opponent raises an objection: But the negative particle...

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ dvitīya padam na mukhya arthakam
translated: The idea is this: The word second does not have its primary meaning.

analyzed: kintu bheda prapañca mātra lakṣakam
translated: But it merely indicates the entire proliferation of difference.

analyzed: nañ padam ca atyanta abhāva arthakam  dvitīyasya abhāvaḥ dvitīyam
translated: And the word not has the meaning of absolute negation.🔽The absence of a second is not-second.

analyzed: artha abhāve vyayībhāvaḥ
translated: In the absence of an object, it is a dvigu compound.

analyzed: tathā ca bheda prapañca bādhaḥ sidhyati advitīya śrutyā iti
translated: And thus the negation of the proliferation of difference is established by the statement not-second.

analyzed: na evam viṣedhaḥ na hi asmādvidīyasya avagamyate
translated: No, there is no negation, for from this [not-second] nothing else is understood.

original: tato 'nyattadviruddhaṃ vā sadṛśaṃ vātra vakti saḥ // //
analyzed: tatas vā sadṛśam vā atra vakti saḥ  /
translated: Therefore, he states here something different from that, or contradictory to that, or similar to that.

analyzed: pariharati na evam iti
translated: He replies: No, it is not so.

analyzed: hiḥ hetau
translated: Hi is a particle indicating reason.

analyzed: yatas smāt advitīya padāt brahma pada samāna adhikaraṇāt dvitīyataḥ bhinna tva ādiḥ eva bodhyate brahmaṇaḥ
translated: Because from this expression without a second, which is co-extensive with the word Brahman, the difference from a second, etc., of Brahman is understood.

analyzed: na tu prapañca niṣedha mātram
translated: But not merely the negation of the world.

analyzed: atas na atra avyayībhāvaḥ yuktaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the avyayibhava compound is not appropriate here, this is the idea.

analyzed: a vikalpitaḥ pi ayam prasaṅgāt pratikṣipyate tra
translated: This [avyayibhava compound] is also rejected incidentally, even though not considered.

analyzed: saḥ advitīya śabdaḥ
translated: That word without a second is...

analyzed: dvitīyam yasya na evā asti tat brahma iti vivakṣite
translated: When it is intended that Brahman is that which has no second at all,

analyzed: satya ādi lakṣaṇa uktīnām apalakṣaṇa tā bhavet
translated: the statements of the definition of Brahman beginning with truth would be non-definitions.

analyzed: anupapannaḥ ca brahma bhinnasya sarvasya niṣedhaḥ
translated: And the negation of everything different from Brahman is not logically possible.

analyzed: tathā sati brahma lakṣaṇa vākyānām asaṅgati prasaṅgāt iti āha dvitīyam iti
translated: Because in that case, the statements of the definition of Brahman would be logically impossible, he says the second, etc.

analyzed: yad saṃbandhinaḥ bhinnasya sarvasya abhāvaḥ
translated: When it is stated that Brahman is that in relation to which there is non-existence of everything different from it,

analyzed: tat brahma iti artha kathane lakṣya vṛtti asādhāraṇa dharma rūpasya lakṣaṇasya api asattvāt satya jñāna ādi lakṣaṇa vākyam apalakṣaṇam bhavet iti bhāvaḥ
translated: the idea is that the definition, which is the uncommon property occurring in the definiendum, would also be non-existent, so the statements of the definition of Brahman beginning with truth would be non-definitions.

analyzed: advitīye dvitīya artha na astitā mātra gocare
translated: In the case of without a second, which has as its scope merely the non-existence of a second object,

analyzed: sva niṣṭha tvāt nañ arthasya na syāt brahma pada anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning of the negative particle being self-contained, there would be no syntactical connection with the word Brahman.

analyzed: avyayībhāvasya sat padena ananvayam api āha advitīyā iti
translated: He says that the avyayibhava compound is not syntactically connected with the word Sat: in the non-dual, etc.

analyzed: a dvitīye a dvitīya pade
translated: In the non-dual, in the word non-dual.

analyzed: sva niṣṭha tvāt sva pradhāna tvāt
translated: Because of self-containment, because of being the primary,

analyzed: itara padārtha aviśeṣaṇa tvāt iti yāvat
translated: that is, because of not being a qualifier of the meaning of the other word.

analyzed: brahma vāci sat pade viśeṣaṇatayā anvayaḥ na syāt
translated: There would be no syntactical connection as a qualifier with the word Sat, which denotes Brahman.

analyzed: tad samāna adhikaraṇam tad viśeṣaṇam hi idam
translated: For this is co-referential with that, it is a qualifier of that.

analyzed: tat na iṣṭa āpattiḥ kartum śakyā
translated: That cannot be accepted as desired.

analyzed: vākya bheda prasaṅgaḥ ca tathā asati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And there would be the undesirable consequence of sentence split, if it were so, is the idea.

analyzed: dvitīya śūnyatā tatra brahmaṇaḥ na viśeṣaṇam
translated: The non-existence of a second there is not a qualifier of Brahman.

original: viśeṣaṇe vā tadbrahma tṛtīyaṃ prathamaṃ tu vā // //
analyzed: viśeṣaṇe vā tat brahma tṛtīyam prathamam tu vā
translated: Or if it is a qualifier, that Brahman is the third or the first.
But if it is argued that the non-existence of a second is Brahman's own nature,

analyzed: tad brahma pada sāmānādhikaraṇyam ghaṭate iti ced tatra āha dvitīya iti
translated: and that co-reference with the word Brahman is possible, then he says in the non-dual, etc.

analyzed: dvitīya abhāvaḥ bhedena brahmaṇaḥ na viśeṣaṇam bhavitum arhati
translated: The non-existence of a second cannot be a qualifier of Brahman without distinction.

analyzed: abhāvasya tuccha tvāt brahmaṇaḥ satya tvāt satya tucchayoḥ aikya ayogāt iti pūrva ardhasya arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the first half is that the non-existence, being a void, and Brahman being real, the identity of the real and the void is not possible.

analyzed: vadāmaḥ dvitīyam pratīyogi prathamam
translated: Even if Brahman is a qualifier, we say the second is the counter-correlate of the first.
The state of being that absence is the second.

analyzed: tṛtīyam ca viśeṣyam brahma
translated: And the third is the qualified Brahman.

analyzed: yat vā brahma prathamam
translated: Or Brahman is the first.

analyzed: dvitīyam pratiyogi dvitīyam
translated: The second is the counter-correlate, the second.

original: tṛtīyaṃ tadabhāvatvaviśeṣaṇamiti prathamatvaṃ tṛtīyatvaṃ vā brahmaṇo 'varjanīyamityuttarārdhārthaḥ /
analyzed: tṛtīyam tad abhāva tva viśeṣaṇam iti prathama tvam tṛtīya tvam vā brahmaṇaḥ varjanīyam iti uttara ardha arthaḥ
translated: The third is the qualifier of the state of being that absence. So the firstness or thirdness of Brahman is unavoidable. This is the meaning of the second half.

analyzed: evam avyayībhāva pakṣe pi anupapattiḥ uktā
translated: Thus, the impossibility is stated even in the case of the avyayibhava compound.

analyzed: prasaktam pūrvavat sarvam bahuḥ vīhau samasyati
translated: As before, all that is relevant is compounded in the bahuvrihi compound.

original: brahmaṇaḥ prathamā ye ca tṛtīyādyā jagatrtraye // //
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ prathamāḥ ye ca tṛtīya ādyāḥ jagatrtraye
translated: And those that are first of Brahman, and the third and so on in the three worlds,

analyzed: brahma prati advitīya tvāt svasthāḥ tiṣṭhanti abādhitāḥ
translated: remain unopposed, abiding in their own state, because Brahman is without a second.

original: kiñca tatra bahuvrīhau samāse saṃśrite sati // //
analyzed: kiñca tatra bahuvrīhau samāse saṃśrite sati
translated: Moreover, when the bahuvrihi compound is resorted to there,

analyzed: vṛtti arthasya nañ arthasya na padārtha antara anvayaḥ
translated: the meaning of the negative particle does not have the relation of being a different word-meaning.

analyzed: satya atyartha antara sambandhe ṣaṣṭhī yasya iti yujyate  /
translated: When there is a relation with a different word-meaning, it is proper to say of which the genitive case is appropriate.

analyzed: atha bahuvrīhi pakṣe dūṣaṇam āha prasaktam iti
translated: Now, in the case of the bahuvrihi compound, he states the fault with the words what is relevant, etc.

analyzed: bahuvrīhi vṛtte pi advitīya pada etatpuruṣaḥ iva prathama tṛtīya ādi sarva sadbhāvaḥ nivāryaḥ prasaktaḥ eva iti arthaḥ
translated: Even in the case of a bahuvrihi compound, as in the tatpurusa compound advitīya, the existence of the first, third, etc. is inevitable and must be accepted. This is the meaning.

analyzed: tat eva upapādayati ardhābhyām brahmaṇaḥ iti
translated: He explains that very thing with two half-verses, beginning with of Brahman.

original: brahmeti ca /🔽nāsti dvitīyaṃ yasya tadbrahmetyatra pakṣe vigrahaḥ /
analyzed: brahma iti ca  na asti dvitīyam yasya tat brahma iti atra pakṣe vigrahaḥ
translated: And Brahman.🔽In the case of the analysis that of which there is no second is Brahman,

analyzed: brahma niṣṭha dvi tva saṅkhyā pūrakam na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is that there is no fulfiller of the number two in relation to Brahman.

original: tathā ca brahmaṇa eva dvitīyatvaṃ labhyeta /
analyzed: tathā ca brahmaṇaḥ eva dvitīya tvam labhyeta
translated: And thus, Brahman itself would obtain the state of being second.

original: tataśca brahmāpekṣayā prathamasya tṛtīyādeśca na bādho 'dvitīyaśrutyetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tatas ca brahma apekṣayā prathamasya tṛtīya ādeḥ ca na bādhaḥ dvitīya śrutyā iti arthaḥ
translated: And from that, there is no contradiction of the first, third, etc. in relation to Brahman by the statement without a second. This is the meaning.

analyzed: ādya saṅkhyā pūraka tvam prathama tvam
translated: The state of being first is the state of being the fulfiller of the number one.

analyzed: tri tva ādi saṅkhyā pūraka tvam ca tṛtīya tva ādi iti bodhyam
translated: And the state of being third, etc. is the state of being the fulfiller of the number three, etc. This should be understood.

analyzed: brahma prati advitīya tvāt brahma apekṣayā dvitīya tva abhāvāt
translated: Because of being without a second in relation to Brahman, there is no state of being second in relation to Brahman.

analyzed: tat ca brahma apekṣayā prathama tvāt tṛtīya ādi tvāt vā
translated: And that is because of the state of being first in relation to Brahman, or because of the state of being third, etc.

analyzed: svasthāḥ ityādi pūrva pad vyākhyeyam
translated: The phrase in their own state should be explained as in the previous verse.

analyzed: nanu bahuvrīhi ghaṭakasya dvitīya padasya dvi tva saṅkhyā pūraka artha tvam
translated: But the second member of the bahuvrihi compound has the meaning of fulfilling the number two.

original: dvitve ca yacchabdārthasya brahmaṇo niṣṭhatvasaṃbandhonānvayo nopeyate /
analyzed: dvi tve ca yad śabda arthasya brahmaṇaḥ niṣṭha tva saṃbandhaḥ ūna anvayaḥ na upeyate
translated: And in the case of duality, the relation of the meaning of the word 'that', which is Brahman, to the state of being the substratum is not admitted,

analyzed: yena prathama tṛtīya ādi prasaktiḥ
translated: by which there would be the possibility of the first, third, etc.

analyzed: kintu dvitīya padam bhinna param
translated: But the second word has a different meaning.

analyzed: bhede ca brahma pratiyogika tvasya anvayaḥ
translated: And in the case of difference, the relation of Brahman being the counter-correlate is admitted.

original: yato brahmaṇo bhinnaṃ nāsti tadbrahmādvitīyamiti dvitīyabādho 'dvitīyaśrutyā labhyata evetyatrāhakiñceti /
analyzed: yatas brahmaṇaḥ bhinnam na asti tat brahma advitīyam iti dvitīya bādhaḥ dvitīya śrutyā labhyate eva iti atra āha kiñca iti
translated: Since there is nothing different from Brahman, that Brahman is non-dual is understood even by the statement 'non-dual'. Here he says 'what is more'.

analyzed: anya padārtha pradhānaḥ hi bahuvrīhiḥ
translated: For the bahuvrihi compound has as its primary meaning the other word.

analyzed: tathā ca bahuvrīhi vṛtta pada upasthāpya dvitīyā bhāvasya anya padārtha brahma viśeṣaṇa tvam vaktavyam
translated: And in that case, the absence of a second, which is denoted by the word occurring in the bahuvrihi compound, must be stated as a qualifier of Brahman, the meaning of the other word.

analyzed: tat na ghaṭate
translated: That is not possible.
The meaning is that in the doctrine that everything is empty except Brahman, the absence of a second, being empty, cannot be a qualifier of the meaning of the word Brahman.

analyzed: vṛtti arthasya bahuvrīhi arthasya
translated: Of the meaning of the bahuvrihi compound, which is the meaning of the word 'existing'.

analyzed: nañ arthasya dvitīyā abhāvasya
translated: Of the meaning of the negative particle, which is the absence of a second.

analyzed: kutas na padārtha antara anvaya asambhavaḥ
translated: How is it impossible for it to be related to another word-meaning?

analyzed: tatra āha satyā iti
translated: There he says 'if it exists'.

original: yasyeti ṣaṣṭhī prakṛtyarthānviter'thāntarasaṃbandhe prāmāṇike sati saṅgacchate /
analyzed: yasya iti ṣaṣṭhī prakṛti artha anvita īrtha antara saṃbandhe prāmāṇike sati saṅgacchate
translated: The genitive case is appropriate when there is a real connection of the meaning of the basic word with another meaning.

original: nirviśeṣe ca brahmaṇi prakṛtyarthe padārthāntarasaṃbandhasyāsatyatvāt ṣaṣṭhībahuvrīhiśca prakṛte na ghaṭata ityarthaḥ // // // //
analyzed: nirviśeṣe ca brahmaṇi prakṛti arthe padārtha antara saṃbandhasya asatya tvāt ṣaṣṭhī bahuvrīhiḥ ca prakṛte na ghaṭate iti arthaḥ
translated: But in Brahman, the meaning of the basic word, which is without distinctions, the connection with another word-meaning is unreal, therefore the genitive and bahuvrīhi compound are not appropriate in the context. This is the meaning.
The second is not an existent, it is not Brahman, nor is it a qualification.

analyzed: asattvāt na hi asat brahma bhavet na api viśeṣaṇam
translated: For what is non-existent cannot be Brahman, nor can it be a qualification.

original: rāhoḥ śira ityādāvabhede 'pi ṣaṣṭhyā dṛṣṭeryadabhinno dvitīyābhāvastadadvitīyaṃ brahmeti vivakṣāṃ pratikṣepati /dvitīyeti /
analyzed: rāhoḥ śiraḥ ityādau abhede ṣaṣṭhyā dṛṣṭeḥ yat abhinnaḥ dvitīya abhāvaḥ tat advitīyam brahma iti vivakṣām pratikṣepati dvitīyā iti
translated: In expressions like the head of Rahu, the genitive is seen even when there is no difference. Therefore, rejecting the intention that Brahman without a second is that where there is no second which is not different, he says the second.

original: asataḥ satpadārthābhedastadviśeṣaṇatvamapi na yujyate iti bhāvaḥ // //
analyzed: asataḥ sat padārtha abhedaḥ tad viśeṣaṇa tvam api na yujyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the difference of the non-existent from existent things, and its being a qualification of it, is not proper.

analyzed: tasmāt prapañca sadbhāvaḥ na advaita śruti bādhitaḥ
translated: Therefore, the existence of the world is not contradicted by the non-dualistic scriptures.

analyzed: sva pramāṇa balāt siddhaḥ śrutyā ca api anumoditaḥ
translated: It is established by the power of its own valid means of knowledge, and is also approved by scripture.

analyzed: para abhimata advitīya śruti artha anupapatti nirūpaṇam nigamayati tasmāt iti
translated: He concludes the examination of the inappropriateness of the meaning of the non-dualistic scriptures accepted by others with therefore.

analyzed: nirdeṣa pratyakṣa ādi pramāṇa siddhaḥ śrutyā api parama artha tvena anuvarṇitaḥ bheda prapañca sadbhāvaḥ na advitīya śruti bādhyaḥ
translated: The existence of the manifold of difference, established by faultless perception and other means of valid knowledge, and described by the scriptures as ultimate reality, is not contradicted by the non-dualistic scriptures.

analyzed: upapādita prakāreṇa advitīya śruteḥ brahma bhinna nāstitā pratipādana asāmarthyāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the non-dualistic scriptures are incapable of establishing the non-existence of what is different from Brahman in the manner explained.

analyzed: iti advitīya śruteḥ para abhimata arthe dūṣaṇa nirūpaṇam
translated: Thus, the refutation of the objections raised by others regarding the meaning intended by the non-dualistic scriptures.

analyzed: tena advitīyam brahma iti śruteḥ arthaḥ yam ucyate
translated: Therefore, the meaning of the scripture Brahman is non-dual is stated as follows.

analyzed: dvitīya gaṇanā yogyaḥ na āsīt asti bhaviṣyati
translated: It has not existed, does not exist, and will not exist as something suitable for counting as a second.

analyzed: samaḥ vā abhyadhikaḥ vā asya yaḥ dvitīyaḥ tugaṇyate
translated: Whatever is counted as its second, whether equal or superior,

analyzed: yatas sya vibhava vyūha kalā mātram idam jagat
translated: since this world is merely a part of its glory and array.

analyzed: dvitīya vāc āspada tām pratipadyeta tat katham
translated: How could it attain the status of being the object of the word second?

analyzed: yathā cola nṛpaḥ samrāj advitīyaḥ bhū tale
translated: And just as the Chola king is the emperor, the second on earth today,

analyzed: iti tad tulya nṛpati nivāraṇa param vacaḥ
translated: So this statement is intended to exclude other kings equal to him,

analyzed: na tu tad bhṛtya tad putra kalatra ādi niṣedhakam
translated: but not to deny his servants, sons, wives, and so on.

analyzed: tathā sura asura nara brahma brahmāṇḍa koṭayaḥ
translated: Similarly, the crores of worlds of gods, demons, humans, Brahmas, and Brahmandas,

analyzed: kleśa karma vipāka ādyaiḥ a spṛṣṭasya akhila īśituḥ
translated: of the all-powerful one untouched by afflictions, karma, results, and so on,

analyzed: jñāna ādi sāṅguṇya nidheḥ acintya vibhavasya tāḥ  viṣṇoḥ vibhūti mahima samudra drapsa vipruṣaḥ
translated: They are the drops of water from the ocean of the glory and greatness of the glory of Vishnu,

analyzed: kaḥ tarhi advitīya śruti arthaḥ
translated: the abode of the six qualities such as knowledge, of inconceivable glory.🔽Then what is the meaning of the statement that there is nothing second to Brahman?

analyzed: tatra ahatena iti
translated: To this he says: by this.

analyzed: para abhimata arthasya anupapattyā anyādṛśaḥ ṛthaḥ su saṅgataḥ upanyasyate smābhiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because the meaning accepted by others is not possible, we are presenting a meaning of a different kind that is very appropriate.

analyzed: ucyate iti pratijñānam ucyamāna arthasya apūrvavat āścarya āvaha tva dyotana artham avadheya tva artham ca
translated: He says: it is said. The meaning of what is being said is declared in order to show that it is as wonderful as something not heard before and in order to make it understood.

analyzed: tam eva artham āha dvitīya iti
translated: He states that very meaning: in the second.

original: prathamato brahmaṇo gaṇane kṛte tena saha gaṇanārhe dvitīyaḥ samo vādhiko vā padārthaḥ kālatraye 'pi nāstītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: prathamatas brahmaṇaḥ gaṇane kṛte tena saha gaṇana arhe dvitīyaḥ samaḥ vā adhikaḥ vā padārthaḥ kāla traye na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: in the enumeration of Brahman first, there is no second object, equal or superior, to be enumerated along with it, in the three times.

analyzed: nanu vividha vicitra ananta cit acit prapañce katham kasyacid api brahma samasyā bhāvaḥ
translated: But how can there be no absence of something equal to Brahman in the various, diverse, infinite universe of conscious and unconscious things?

analyzed: tatra ahayata eti
translated: To this he says: by that.

analyzed: asya paramātmanaḥ nanta mahā vibhūteḥ vibhūti eka deśa aṃśa mātra tvāt caturdaśa bhuvana ātmaka brahmāṇḍa koṭeḥ api
translated: And because the fourteen worlds, the universe, are only a part of the glory of this supreme Self, of its infinite, great glory,

analyzed: tad antargatasya udumbara maśaka vat paricchinna sva rūpa svabhāva ādeḥ bhava brahma ādeḥ api na
translated: Even for Bhava, Brahma, and others, who have a limited nature and essence like a mosquito inside a fig fruit,

analyzed: tena sāmya gandha prasaṅgaḥ iti dvitīya vāc āspa da tām dvitīya pada vācya tām
translated: Even for Bhava, Brahma, etc., whose nature is limited like a mosquito inside a fig fruit, there is no possibility of being equal to that, so the second word is fit to be expressed by the second word.

analyzed: brahmaṇā saha gaṇanā yogya tvam
translated: Being worthy of being counted along with Brahman.

analyzed: katham tat jagat pratipadyeta prāpnuyāt iti arthaḥ
translated: How would that world attain, i.e., reach? This is the meaning.

analyzed: siddhānte dvitīya padasya vṛtti dvayam api saṃbhavati iti abhipretam
translated: It is intended that in the established conclusion, both usages of the word second are possible.

original: tathā cānugṛhītaṃ śatadūṣaṇyāṃ śrīmadvedāntadeśikacaraṇaiḥasmatpakṣe tu vṛttidvayamapi samyak /
analyzed: tathā ca anugṛhītam śatadūṣaṇyām śrīmat vedānta deśika caraṇaiḥ asmad pakṣe tu vṛtti dvayam api samyak
translated: And thus it is favored in the Shatadushani by the illustrious feet of Vedantadeshika: But in our view, both usages are correct.

analyzed: dvitīya vyatireka uktyā sataḥ syāt agragaṇya tā
translated: By stating the second exclusion, the existent would not be counted first.

analyzed: dvitīya śūnyatā uktyā ca tad samāna niṣedhakam
translated: And by stating the second emptiness, it negates that which is similar to it.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: etat vyākurmahe atiśayita vastu gaṇanā prastāve brahmaṇaḥ eva prathama parigaṇanam nyāyyam
translated: We explain this: In the context of counting the collection of superior things, it is proper to count Brahman first.

analyzed: tasya eva mukhya atiśayavat tvāt
translated: Because only it has the principal superiority.

original: mukhyasyaiva prathamaparigaṇanasya loke śāstre ca dṛṣṭeḥ /
analyzed: mukhyasya eva prathama parigaṇanasya loke śāstre ca dṛṣṭeḥ
translated: Because in the world and in the scriptures, only the principal is seen to be counted first.

original: kavikulagaṇanāprasaṅge kālidāsasyaiva hi prāthamyena gaṇanaṃ kavilokaprasiddham /
analyzed: kavi kula gaṇanā prasaṅge kālidāsasya eva hi prāthamyena gaṇanam kavi loka prasiddham
translated: In the context of counting poets, it is well-known among poets that only Kālidāsa is counted first.

analyzed: yathā ucyate purā kavīnām gaṇanā prasaṅge kaniṣṭhika adhiṣṭhita kālidāsāḥ iti
translated: As it is said, In the context of counting poets, Kālidāsa is considered the youngest.

analyzed: śāstra kṛtaḥ jaimineḥ ācāryasya api saṃmatam mukhyasya prathama parigaṇanam
translated: Even Jaimini, the author of the treatise, accepts the primary counting of the teacher.

analyzed: tathā hi sūtrayāmāsa mukhyam vā pūrva codanāt loka vat iti
translated: Thus he formulated the aphorism: The primary [view] is due to the earlier injunction, like in the world.

analyzed: evam nañ tatpuruṣe brahmaṇaḥ eva agragaṇya tā sthitā
translated: Thus, in the tatpuruṣa compound with the negative particle, Brahman alone is counted first.
Then the establishment of being the basis of all follows.

analyzed: tatas ca adhika niṣedhaḥ phalati
translated: And then the prohibition of the superior becomes fruitful.

original: samasyaiva dvitīyagaṇanāyogyatvamityāśayamūlakaṃ capurā kavīnāmitiślokasyottarārdhaṃ paripaṭhyate adyāpi tattulyakaverabhāvādanāmikā sār'thavatī
analyzed: samasya eva dvitīya gaṇanā yogya tvam iti āśaya mūlakam ca purā kavīnām iti ślokasya uttara ardham paripaṭhyate adyā api tad tulya kaveḥ abhāvāt anāmikā sārthavatī
translated: The second counting is appropriate only for the equal one. The second half of the verse In the past, in the context of counting poets... is recited with this intention, Even today, because there is no poet equal to him, the little finger remains meaningful.

analyzed: babhūva eti
translated: It became.

original: tathā ca bahuvrīhivṛttyā samaniṣedhaḥ phalati brahmaṇa iti /
analyzed: tathā ca bahuvrīhi vṛttyā sama niṣedhaḥ phalati brahmaṇaḥ iti
translated: And thus, by the operation of the bahuvrīhi compound, the prohibition of the equal becomes fruitful with respect to Brahman.

original: muktānāmapi bhogamātrasāmyamiti na brahmaṇā saha gaṇanaṃ mukhyaparigaṇanaprastāve yuktam /
analyzed: muktānām api bhoga mātra sāmyam iti na brahmaṇā saha gaṇanam mukhya parigaṇana prastāve yuktam
translated: Even among the liberated ones, there is equality only in mere enjoyment. Therefore, it is not proper to count them along with Brahman in the context of primary counting.

original: tanmukhyaṃ vastu vastuto brahmaikameveti advitīyatvaṃ tasya pratitiṣṭhatīti ca bodhyam /
analyzed: tat mukhyam vastu vastutas brahma ekam eva iti advitīya tvam tasya pratitiṣṭhati iti ca bodhyam
translated: It should be understood that the primary object is Brahman itself, and thus its non-duality is established.

analyzed: evam advitīya śruteḥ brahmaṇaḥ sama abhyadhika rāhitya pratipādana para tvam vyavasthāpitam
translated: Thus, the non-duality statement is established as conveying the idea that Brahman is without equal or superior.

original: na tatsamaścābhyadhikaśca dṛśyate iti śrutyantarānusārātna tvatsamo 'styabhyadhikaḥ
analyzed: na tad samaḥ ca abhyadhikaḥ ca dṛśyate iti śruti antara anusārāt na tvad samaḥ sti abhyadhikaḥ
translated: In accordance with another scriptural passage, No one equal or superior to Him is seen, and in accordance with the amplification, There is none like You, much less greater, the idea that His nature is proper is in the heart.

original: kuto 'nyo lokatraye 'pyapratimaprabhāva ityupabṛṃhaṇānusārāccaidamarthyameva tasya nyāyyamiti hārdam /🔽athādvitīyapadasya samāntaraniṣedhaparatve laukikaprayogaṃ ca nidarśayatiyatheti /
analyzed: kutas nyaḥ lokatraye pi apratima prabhāvaḥ iti upabṛṃhaṇa anusārāt ca edamarthyam eva tasya nyāyyam iti hārdam  atha advitīya padasya samā antara niṣedha paratve laukika prayogam ca nidarśayati yathā iti
translated: Now, in the case of the word non-dual, if it means the negation of a similar thing, he gives an example of ordinary usage: As follows.

original: colanṛpasyāsthānapaṇḍitaṃ vijityavādāhaverājāsanaṃ rājyārdhaṃ ca tatsamarpitamadhigatavanta ime paramācāryāḥ pūrvāśrame /
analyzed: cola nṛpasya āsthāna paṇḍitam vijitya vāda āhave rāja āsanam rājya ardham ca tad samarpitam adhigatavantaḥ ime parama ācāryāḥ pūrva āśrame
translated: These supreme teachers, in their previous stage of life, having defeated the court-scholar of the Chola king in a debate, obtained the royal throne and half of his kingdom.

analyzed: tad prasaṅga smārakaḥ ca ayam
translated: And this mention of the Chola king is a reminder of that occasion.

analyzed: yathā rājñaḥ dvitīya tva varṇanam rāja vibhūti ādeḥ niṣedhakam na
translated: Just as the description of the king's non-duality is not a negation of royal glory and so on,

analyzed: kintu tad sama nṛpa antara niṣedhakam eva
translated: But that is only a negation of other rulers equal to him.

analyzed: evam brahmaṇaḥ dvitīya tva śrutiḥ na tad vibhūteḥ niṣedhikā iti āha tathā iti
translated: Similarly, the statement about Brahman being without a second does not negate its glory. He says thus.

analyzed: atra yāḥ iti a patitam
translated: Here, ya (which) is omitted.

analyzed: yāḥ sura asura nara brahma garbha brahmāṇḍa koṭayaḥ
translated: As many millions of worlds containing gods, demons, humans, and Brahmā,

original: tā veṣṇavamahāvibhūtyarṇavaviśīryamāṇa jalakaṇikāyamānāḥ tadadvitīyatvaśrutyā na bādhyanta iti yāvat /
analyzed: tāḥ jalakaṇikāyamānāḥ tad advitīya tva śrutyā na bādhyante iti yāvat
translated: they are considered to be like the tiny water droplets scattered from the great ocean of Viṣṇu's glory. This is the extent of the statement that they are not contradicted by the statement about his being without a second.

original: aupaniṣadaṃ paraṃ tattvaṃ paraṃ brahma śrīmannārāyaṇa eveti ca viṣṇoriti nirdeśena jñāpitam // // // // // // //🔽kaḥ khalvaṅgulibhaṅgena samudrān saptasaṅkhyā /
analyzed: aupaniṣadam param tattvam param brahma śrīmat nārāyaṇaḥ eva iti ca viṣṇoḥ iti nirdeśena jñāpitam  kaḥ khalu aṅguli bhaṅgena samudrān sapta saṅkhyā
translated: And it is indicated by the statement of Viṣṇu that the highest truth of the Upaniṣads is none other than the glorious Nārāyaṇa, the Supreme Brahman.

analyzed: gaṇayan gaṇayet ūrmi phena budbuda vipruṣaḥ
translated: Who, indeed, can count the waves, foam, bubbles, and drops of water in the ocean by counting the seven oceans with a finger snap?

original: yathaika eva savitā na dvitīyo nabhaḥsthale /
analyzed: yathā ekaḥ eva savitā na dvitīyaḥ nabhaḥ sthale
translated: Just as there is only one sun, not a second, in the sky and on the earth,

original: ityuktā na hi sāvitrā niṣidhyante 'tra raśmayaḥ // //🔽yathā pradhānasaṅkhyeyasaṅkhyāyāṃ naiva gaṇyate /
analyzed: iti uktāḥ na hi sāvitrāḥ niṣidhyante raśmayaḥ  yathā pradhāna saṅkhyeya saṅkhyāyām na eva gaṇyate
translated: thus stated, the sun's rays are not prohibited here by the statement about the sun.🔽Just as the number is not counted separately in the enumeration of the principal object to be counted,

analyzed: saṅkhyā pṛthak satī tatra saṅkhyeyā anya padārtha vat
translated: like other objects to be counted, the number exists there.

analyzed: nanu atulya tve pi saha gaṇanā iṣyatām iti atra āhakaḥ iti
translated: If it is not similar, it may be counted together. To this he says 'ka'.

original: tatsvarūpāntargatasya tena saha gaṇanāyoga ityatredaṃ nidarśanam /
analyzed: tad svarūpa antargatasya tena saha gaṇanā yogaḥ iti atra idam nidarśanam
translated: This is an example of the appropriateness of counting together what is included in its own nature with it.

original: savitṛnidarśanaṃ ca /🔽guṇasya guṇinā saha gaṇanāyoga ityatrayathā pradhāneti /
analyzed: savitṛ nidarśanam ca  guṇasya guṇinā saha gaṇanā yogaḥ iti atra yathā pradhāna iti
translated: And the example of the sun.🔽In this case, the appropriateness of counting together the quality with the possessor of the quality is like 'in the principal'.

analyzed: pṛthak satī saṅkhyeyāt bhinna tvena sthitā
translated: Existing separately, it is distinct from what is to be counted.

analyzed: yat vā apṛthak sati iti chedaḥ  apṛthak siddha viśeṣaṇa bhūta iti arthaḥ
translated: Or the break is 'not separately'.🔽The meaning is that it is a distinguishing feature not established separately.

original: saṅkhyeyānyapadārthavaditi tu vaidharmyadṛṣṭāntaḥ /🔽saṅkhyeyadravyagaṇanāyāṃ saṅkhyeyo 'nyaḥ padārtho yathā gaṇyate na tathā tadguṇabhūtā saṅkhyā tena saha gaṇyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: saṅkhyeya anya padārtha vat iti tu vaidharmya dṛṣṭāntaḥ  saṅkhyeya dravya gaṇanāyām saṅkhyeyaḥ nyaḥ padārthaḥ yathā gaṇyate na tathā tad guṇa bhūtā saṅkhyā tena saha gaṇyate iti arthaḥ
translated: But the example of dissimilarity is 'like the other objects to be counted'.🔽The meaning is that the number which is a quality of that is not counted together with it, as the other object to be counted is counted in the counting of the countable substance.🔽Or the meaning is 'like the other thing not mentioned as countable'.

analyzed: yat vā saṅkhyeya tvena aprastuta vastu antara vat iti arthaḥ  sādharmya dṛṣṭānta tvam idānīm ghaṭate
translated: Now the example of similarity fits...

original: tathā / pādo 'sya viśvā bhūtāni tripādasyāmṛtaṃ divi /
analyzed: tathā pādaḥ u sya viśvā bhūtāni tri pādasya amṛtam divi
translated: Similarly, 'His foot is all beings, his three feet are in the immortal heaven.'

analyzed: iti bruvan jagat sarvam itthambhāve nyaveśayat  /
translated: Saying this, he placed the entire world in this state.

analyzed: nanu sarvam tadā śobhanam
translated: But then everything is beautiful.

analyzed: yadi brahma vibhūti tva ādau pramāṇam syāt iti atra āha tathā iti
translated: If there were a means of knowledge regarding the state of being a manifestation of Brahman, etc., here it is said thus.

analyzed: pādaḥ sya iti
translated: This is his foot.

original: yathā brahmaguṇatvaṃ sidhyejjagataḥ tathaiva brahmāṃśatvaṃ pratipādayacchrutijātaṃ sarvaṃ jagata brahmāpṛthaksiddhaprakāratve vyavārthāpayadityarthaḥ
analyzed: yathā brahma guṇa tvam sidhyet jagataḥ tathā eva brahma aṃśa tvam pratipādayat śruti jātam sarvam brahmā apṛthak siddha prakāra tve
translated: All the scriptural passages that teach the world to be a part of Brahman in the same way that its qualities are established, explain that the world is not of a different kind from Brahman, which is established separately.

analyzed: guṇa tvam ca atyanta pāratantrya rūpam itthambhāva śabditam apṛthak siddha prakāra tva lakṣaṇam eva
translated: And being a quality means being absolutely dependent, called being thus, which is characterized by not being of a different kind from what is established separately.

analyzed: itthambhāvaḥ iti anena na svarūpa eka deśa tva lakṣaṇam aṃśa tvam
translated: By this being thus it is not indicated that being a part means being a part of the nature itself.

analyzed: kintu viśiṣṭa brahma svarūpa antargata prakāra tā eka rūpatva lakṣaṇam eva jagataḥ brahma aṃśa tvam iti vyajyate  /
translated: But it is indicated that the world being a part of Brahman means having the nature of being of the same kind as the distinguished nature of Brahman.

original: tathā / etāvānasya mahimā tato jyāyastaro hi saḥ /
analyzed: tathā etāvān asya mahimā tatas jyāyastaraḥ hi saḥ
translated: Thus. His greatness is this much, but he is greater than that.

analyzed: yatra anyat na vijānāti sa bhūma udaram antaram
translated: Where he does not know anything else, he is the belly of the earth.

analyzed: kurute sya bhayam vyaktam ityādi śrutayaḥ parāḥ
translated: The manifest fear of him, etc., are the supreme scriptures.

analyzed: meroḥ iva aṇuḥ yasya idam brahmāṇḍam akhilam jagat
translated: Like an atom of Meru, this entire universe is his.

analyzed: ityādikāḥ samastasya tad itthambhāva tā aparāḥ
translated: All these [passages] are intent on the nature of that [Brahman] of the entire [universe].

analyzed: brahma svarūpa eka deśa tvam eva jagataḥ kutas na iti atrāha tathā iti
translated: How is it that the world is not a part of the nature of Brahman? To this he says 'thus'.

original: etāvāniti /🔽mahimā ityanena jagato vibhūtitvaṃ brahmaṇo 'tiśayāvahatvādguṇatvaṃ ca jñāyate /
analyzed: etāvān iti  mahimā iti anena jagataḥ vibhūti tvam brahmaṇaḥ utiśaya āvaha tvāt guṇa tvam ca jñāyate
translated: 'This much' [means]🔽'glory'. By this it is known that the world is an effect of Brahman and is a quality [of Brahman] because it enhances Brahman's excellence.

original: tato jyāyāṃśca pūruṣa iti brahmaṇo jagadapekṣayātivailakṣaṇyaṃ ca /
analyzed: tatas jyāyān ca pūruṣaḥ iti brahmaṇaḥ jagat apekṣayā ati vailakṣaṇyam ca
translated: 'And the Person is greater than that' [means] Brahman is very different from the world.

original: ato na brahmasvarūpaikadeśatā mṛdaṃśateva tatpariṇāmaghaṭāderjagato yuktā /
analyzed: atas na brahma svarūpa eka deśa tā mṛd aṃśa tā iva tad pariṇāma ghaṭa ādeḥ jagataḥ yuktā
translated: Therefore, the world is not rightly [said to be] a part of Brahman's nature, like a part of a clay pot [is a part of] the clay from which it is produced.

analyzed: pṛthak siddha viśeṣaṇa tayā viśiṣṭa eka vastu eka deśa tva rūpam eva brahma aṃśatvam jagataḥ bhimatam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the intended meaning is that the world is a part of Brahman in the sense of being a part of a single entity qualified by a distinguishing feature that is not established separately [from the whole].

analyzed: sarvasya brahma svarūpa antargata tve śrutim udāharati yatra iti
translated: In order to cite a scriptural passage that everything is included within Brahman's nature, [the author] says 'where'.

original: yatra viśiṣṭe brahmaṇi samanubhūyamāne 'nyatsvatantraṃ vastu na paśyati /
analyzed: yatra viśiṣṭe brahmaṇi samanubhūyamāne vastu na paśyati
translated: Where, in Brahman qualified [by the world], when experienced, one does not see anything else independent [of Brahman].

analyzed: sarvasya tad antarbhāvāt
translated: Because everything is included within that.

analyzed: sa bhūmā iti arthaḥ
translated: That is the meaning of 'bhūman'.

original: sarvaprakārakaḥ sarvātmā paraṃ brahma paramapuruṣo nārāyaṇa eva bhūmā /
analyzed: sarva prakārakaḥ sarva ātmā param brahma parama puruṣaḥ nārāyaṇaḥ eva bhūmā
translated: The all-pervading, the soul of all, the supreme Brahman, the supreme Person, Narayana alone is the bhūman.

analyzed: anyaḥ sarvaḥ pi alpakaḥ iti proktam bhavati
translated: It is said that all else is very small.

original: svaniṣṭhaprañcadarśananindayā ca brahmaniṣṭhatvameva tasya gamyata ityāśayena śrutyantaramupādatte udaramiti /
analyzed: sva niṣṭha prañca darśana nindayā ca brahma niṣṭha tvam eva tasya gamyate iti āśayena śruti antaram upādatte udaram iti
translated: And with the censure of the view of the five as one's own, it is understood that it has Brahman as its basis. With this intention, he quotes another śruti: Udara (belly).

analyzed: yadā hi eva eṣa etasmin nu daram antaram kurute
translated: When indeed he makes an opening in this belly,

analyzed: atha tasya bhayam bhavati iti taittirīya upaniṣadi
translated: then fear comes to him, in the Taittiriya Upanishad.

original: etasmin prapañce daramalpamapi antaramantarālaṃ brahmasaṃbandhavicchedaṃ yadā paśyati tadaivāsyaivaṃ jānataḥ saṃsārabhayamupasthitamagre bhavatītyarthaḥ
analyzed: etasmin prapañce daram alpam api antaram antarālam brahma saṃbandha vicchedam yadā paśyati tadā eva asya evam jānataḥ saṃsāra bhayam upasthitam agre bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: When one sees even a small opening, an interval, a separation from Brahman, in this world, then the fear of worldly existence appears before him who knows thus. This is the meaning.

original: paraprakriyācchāyayaivamatrārtho vivakṣito bhedamithyātvaṃ na sidhyatyetadvākyata iti bodhanāya /
analyzed: para prakriyā chāyayā evam atra arthaḥ vivakṣitaḥ bheda mithyātvam na sidhyati etad vākyataḥ iti bodhanāya
translated: The meaning intended here is stated by the shadow of another's explanation, in order to show that the unreality of difference is not established by this statement.

original: paramātmani niṣṭhāśabditasya dhruvānusmaraṇasya pūrvavākyaprastutasyālpakālavicchede 'pi saṃsārabhayaprasaṅga eveti tu siddhāntisammator'thaḥ
analyzed: paramātmani niṣṭhā śabditasya dhruva anusmaraṇasya pūrva vākya prastutasya alpa kāla vicchede saṃsāra bhaya prasaṅgaḥ eva iti tu siddhānti sammatā ūrthaḥ
translated: The settled meaning is that even a brief separation from the constant remembrance called resting in the supreme self, which is the subject of the previous statement, leads to the danger of worldly existence.

analyzed: viṣṇu mahā vibhūti eka deśa tve jagataḥ smṛti vākyam meroḥ ityādi
translated: The smrti statement Meru etc. is with regard to the world being a part of the great manifestation of Vishnu.

analyzed: ityādayaḥ iti asya agre smṛtayaḥ ca iti yojyam
translated: The words and so on should be connected after remembrances.

analyzed: tad itthambhāva tā parāḥ brahma apṛthak siddha prakāra tva pratipādana tatparāḥ
translated: They are intent on the state of being thus - they are intent on teaching the way of the non-difference of Brahman and the world.

analyzed: vācā ārambhaṇa mātram tu jagat sthāvara jaṅgamam
translated: The world of moving and unmoving beings is mere verbal expression.

analyzed: vikāra jātam
translated: The world of modifications.

analyzed: kūṭastham mūla kāraṇam eva sat
translated: The immutable, the primary cause alone is real.

original: nanu virukteṣu vacaneṣu brahmavibhūtitvādau jagataḥ pratipādite 'pi vacanāntareṣu
analyzed: nanu virukteṣu vacaneṣu brahma vibhūti tva ādau jagataḥ pratipādite vacana antareṣu
translated: But even when the world is taught to be a modification of Brahman and so on in contradictory statements, in other statements

original: kāraṇamātrasya satyatvam anyasya sarvasyāsatyatvaṃ ca pratīyate iti tadanurodheneṣāṃ
analyzed: kāraṇa mātrasya satya tvam anyasya sarvasya asatya tvam ca pratīyate iti tad anurodhena iṣām
translated: the reality of the cause alone and the unreality of everything else is understood. Therefore, in accordance with that,

analyzed: vyāvahārika viṣaya tvam eva mantavyam iti ced tatra āha vācā iti
translated: it should be understood that these statements have only the conventional world as their object. If this is argued, then he says wa and so on.

analyzed: vacana antareṣu api mithyātvam nā ucyate bheda prapañcasya
translated: Even in other statements, the falsity of the manifold of differences is not stated.

original: kintu brahmātmakatvena sattaiveti bhāvaḥ /🔽śrautakatipayapadaghaṭitaṃ śrautārthānuvādarūpaṃ vācārambhaṇamātramityādi /
analyzed: kintu brahma ātmaka tvena sattā eva iti bhāvaḥ  śrauta katipaya pada ghaṭitam śrauta artha anuvāda rūpam vācā ārambhaṇa mātram ityādi
translated: But the meaning is that it is real only as having Brahman as its essence.🔽The statement beginning with vācārambhaṇa is a restatement of the heard meaning, consisting of a few words from the scriptures.

analyzed: tad tad pada smāritāni śruti vākyāni vivakṣitāni
translated: The scriptural sentences recalled by those words are intended.

original: vācā'sambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyaṃ mṛttiketyeva satyamiti cchāndogye ṣaṣṭhaprapāṭhake /🔽vācā iti tṛtīyā prayojanasya hetutvavivakṣayā /
analyzed: vikāraḥ nāmadheyam mṛttikā iti eva satyam iti chāndogye ṣaṣṭha prapāṭhake  vācā iti tṛtīyā prayojanasya hetu tva vivakṣayā
translated: The modification and the name are mere verbal expressions, earth and truth are real, in the sixth section of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.🔽The instrumental case in vācā is used to indicate the purpose as the cause.

analyzed: ārambhaṇam ālambhavam spṛṣṭam
translated: The modification is touched by the verbal expression.

analyzed: ālambhaḥ sparśa hiṃsayoḥ
translated: Ālambha means touching and injuring.

analyzed: gṛhītam iti yāvat
translated: It means grasped.

analyzed: ārambhate iti ārambhaṇam sṛṣṭam iti vā
translated: Or it means that which is modified.

analyzed: napuṃsaka ekaśeṣa ekavadbhāvau
translated: The neuter form and the singular number are used.

analyzed: kintat vikāraḥ nāmadheyam ca
translated: But what is that? The modification and the name.

original: kena spṛṣṭamityākāṅkṣāyāṃntvetha yathā somyaikena mṛtpiṇḍeneti pūrvaprakṛto mṛtpiṇḍo yogyatvātkartṛtayānveti /
analyzed: kena spṛṣṭam iti ākāṅkṣāyām yathā somya ekena mṛd piṇḍena iti pūrva prakṛtaḥ mṛd piṇḍaḥ yogya tvāt kartṛtayā anveti
translated: When there is a desire to know by what it is touched, then the previously mentioned lump of clay is connected as the agent by suitability.

original: ghaṭatvādyavasthārūpo vikāraḥ tattadavasthāyogaprayuktaṃ ghaṭādināma ca mṛtpiṇḍenaiva gṛhītaṃ vākpūrvakavyavahārāyeti phalitam /
analyzed: ghaṭa tva ādi avasthā rūpaḥ vikāraḥ tad tad avasthā yoga prayuktam ghaṭa ādi nāma ca mṛd piṇḍena eva gṛhītam vāc pūrvaka vyavahārāya iti phalitam
translated: The meaning is that the modification in the form of the state of a pot etc. and the name of the pot etc. caused by the connection with that state are grasped only by the lump of clay for the purpose of verbal usage preceded by speech.

original: evaṃ kāraṇadravyasyaiva nānāvasthābhāktvena nānākāryātmakatvātkāryāṇāṃ kāraṇānanyatvamityāhamṛttiketyeva satyamiti /
analyzed: evam kāraṇa dravyasya eva nānā avasthā bhāj tvena nānā kārya ātmaka tvāt kāryāṇām kāraṇa ananyatvam iti āha mṛttikā iti eva satyam iti
translated: Thus, since the causal substance itself has many effects due to having many states, I say that the effects are not different from the causes, as stated in earth and truth.

analyzed: atra sarvam mṛṇmayam viśeṣyam
translated: Here, everything made of clay is the qualifier.

analyzed: iti śabdaḥ prakāra vācī
translated: The word 'iti' (thus) denotes a kind.

analyzed: sarvam mṛṇmayam mṛttikā tva prakāreṇa eva prāmāṇikam
translated: Everything made of clay is valid only in the sense of being clay,

analyzed: na tu mṛdana ātmaka tvena iti arthaḥ
translated: not in the sense of not being clay itself. This is the meaning.

analyzed: anena kāṇāda abhimataḥ upādāna upādeyayoḥ atyanta bhedaḥ nirastaḥ
translated: By this, the absolute difference between the material cause and the effect, which is accepted by the followers of Kanada, is refuted.

original: ekavijñānena sarvavijñānapratijñopapādanārthaṃ pravṛttatvādasya vākyasyopādānopādeyayorananyatva eva tātparyamuktadiśā /
analyzed: eka vijñānena sarva vijñāna pratijñā upapādana artham pravṛtta tvāt asya vākyasya upādāna upādeyayoḥ ananyatve eva tātparyam ukta diśā
translated: Since this statement is made to explain the promise of knowing everything by knowing one thing, its purport is only in the non-difference of the material cause and the effect, as explained above.

analyzed: na tu kārya mātrasya mithyātve
translated: But not in the falsity of the effect alone.

original: tathā sati sarvasya jñātavyasyābhāvādeva sarvaṃ jñātaṃ syādityasaṅgatamāpadyeta /
analyzed: tathā sati sarvasya jñātavyasya abhāvāt eva sarvam jñātam syāt iti asaṅga tam āpadyeta
translated: If that were so, then because of the absence of everything to be known, everything would be known. Thus it would become incoherent.

analyzed: samasta pada tve para abhimate vāc ārambhaṇam iti bhavet
translated: If the entire word is accepted by the opponent, it would be 'vāgārambhaṇa' (having speech as its source).

analyzed: vācā ārambhaṇa śabdasya mithyā arthaka tvam ca aprasiddham eva para abhimatam iti bodhyam
translated: It should be understood that the meaning of the word 'vācārambhaṇa' (having speech as its origin) as false is not accepted by the opponent.

analyzed: tat satyam iti asya arthataḥ nuvādaḥ kūṭastham ityādiḥ
translated: The meaning of 'tat satyam' (that is true) is restated by 'kūṭastham' (unchanging) and so on.

analyzed: upādāna tve pi brahmaṇaḥ nirvikāra tvam kūṭastha śabdena vivakṣitam
translated: Even though Brahman is the material cause, its changelessness is intended by the word 'kūṭastha' (unchanging).

analyzed: sat satyam satata eka rūpam
translated: 'Sat' (existent) and 'satya' (true) have the same meaning. It is always of one form.

original: nanu nirvikāratve kathamupādānatvam /🔽sarvacidaciccharīrakatvāt sūkṣmacidacidviśiṣṭatvenopādānatvaṃ brahmaṇa upapannameva /
analyzed: nanu nirvikāra tve katham upādāna tvam  sarva cit acit śarīraka tvāt sūkṣma cit acit viśiṣṭa tvena upādāna tvam brahmaṇaḥ upapannam eva
translated: But how can Brahman be the material cause, if it is without modifications?🔽Because it is the body of all that is conscious and unconscious, it is quite proper to say that Brahman is the material cause, as being the subtle cause of all that is conscious and unconscious.

original: so 'yaṃ śarīrātmabhāvo jagadbrahmaṇoḥsadāyatanāḥ aitadātmyamidaṃ sarvamiti nirdiṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: saḥ yam śarīra ātma bhāvaḥ jagat brahmaṇoḥ sat āyatanāḥ aitadātmyam idam sarvam iti nirdiṣṭaḥ
translated: This relation of the world to Brahman as body to Self is indicated by the passage, He is the Self of all, all has that for its Self.

analyzed: na ca evam svarūpa pariṇāma abhāve mṛṇmaya dṛṣṭānta asaṅgatiḥ
translated: Nor is the instance of the clay and the rest irrelevant, if there is no modification of the Self.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇayoḥ ananyatva mātre dṛṣṭānta saṅgateḥ
translated: For the instance is relevant, if the effect is non-different from the cause.

analyzed: nanu cetana acetana prapañcasya brahma ananyatvam vā katham
translated: But how can the world of conscious and unconscious beings be non-different from Brahman?

analyzed: brahma ātmaka tvena brahma rūpa tvena ananyatva upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is Brahman in essence, it is Brahman in form, and so it is proper to say that it is non-different from Brahman.

original: tadidameva prāmāṇikamiti cocyate etadātmyamidaṃ sarvaṃ tatsatyamityekavākyatayānvayāt /
analyzed: tat idam eva prāmāṇikam iti ca ucyate etat ātmyam idam sarvam tat satyam iti ekavākyatayā anvayāt
translated: And this is said to be the only authoritative view, because the passage, He is the Self of all, all has that for its Self, is construed as one sentence with the passage, That is Truth, that is the Self.

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta vākya anuguṇaḥ ca ayam eva arthaḥ iti dhyeyam
translated: And it should be understood that this meaning is in accordance with the instance.

original: paravyākhyācchāyayā tu tadbrahma satyaṃ sadaikarūpamityartho varṇitaḥ /
analyzed: para vyākhyā chāyayā tu tat brahma satyam sadā eka rūpam iti arthaḥ varṇitaḥ
translated: But by the shadow of another's explanation, the meaning is described as that Brahman is Truth, existent, and of one form.

analyzed: śloka iva ācā ārambhaṇa mātram iti asya vāc pūrva vyavahārāya eva niṣpannam kārtsnyena iti arthaḥ
translated: In the verse, the meaning is that what is mere verbal expression is accomplished only for the sake of verbal usage, in its entirety.

analyzed: ananyat kāraṇāt kāryam pāvakāt visphuliṅga vat
translated: The effect is not different from the cause, like sparks from fire.

analyzed: mṛttikā loha bīja ādi nānā dṛṣṭānta vistaraiḥ
translated: With various examples like clay, metal, seed, etc., in detail.

analyzed: samāna prakaraṇeṣu upādāna upādeyayoḥ aikyasya eva pratipādanāt ca na kāryasya mithyātvam vācārambhaṇa śruteḥ arthaḥ
translated: And because oneness of the material cause and the effect is taught in the same context, the meaning of the statement mere verbal expression is not that the effect is false.

analyzed: kintu kāraṇa ātmaka tā eva iti pratibodhayan āha ananyat iti
translated: But it is to awaken the understanding that it has the nature of the cause itself. He says not different etc.

original: pāpakādvyucca ritānāṃ visphuliṅgānāmagnyaṃśatvenāgnyananyatvavadbrahmaṇa udbhūtasya prapañcasyāpi brahmāṃśabhūtasya brahmānanyatvameva vivakṣitam
analyzed: pāpakāt vyucca ritānām visphuliṅgānām agni aṃśa tvena agni ananyatva vat brahmaṇaḥ udbhūtasya prapañcasya api brahma aṃśa bhūtasya brahma ananyatvam eva vivakṣitam
translated: Just as sparks, which are separated from the bad, are not different from fire as being a part of fire, so also the universe, which is evolved from Brahman, is intended to be not different from Brahman as being a part of Brahman.

original: idaṃ cānanyatvaṃ mṛdādidṛṣṭāntaiśca śrutiṣu nirūpitamiti yāvat // //
analyzed: idam ca ananyatvam mṛd ādi dṛṣṭāntaiḥ ca śrutiṣu nirūpitam iti yāvat
translated: And this non-difference is established in the scriptures with examples like clay and so on. That is the meaning.

analyzed: na aśakat dagdhum analaḥ tṛṇam majjayitum jalam
translated: Fire could not burn the grass, water could not submerge it,

analyzed: na vāyuḥ calitum śaktaḥ tad śakti āpyāyanāt ṛte
translated: and wind could not move it, without being nourished by that power.

analyzed: kāryāṇām kāraṇa ātmaka tve upattiḥ uktā
translated: The reason for the effect having the nature of the cause has been stated.

analyzed: arthavāda rūpam api tātparya liṅgam asti iti āha nāśakat iti
translated: There is also an indication of purport in the form of explanatory passages. He says naśakada etc.

analyzed: kena upaniṣadi prasiddhaḥ yam arthaḥ
translated: This meaning is well-known in the Keṇa Upaniṣad.

analyzed: eka pradhāna vijñānāt vijñātam akhilam bhavet  ityādi veda vacana tad mūla āpta āgamaiḥ api
translated: By knowing the one principal thing, everything would be known.

analyzed: brahma ātmanā ātmalābhaḥ yam prapañcaḥ cit acit mayaḥ
translated: Thus it is known that the attainment of the self is through the Brahman-self, and the world consisting of consciousness and non-consciousness,

analyzed: iti pramīyate brāhmī vibhūtiḥ na niṣidhyate
translated: The glory of Brahman is known thus, and is not denied.

original: nanuuta tamādeśamaprākṣyoyenāśrataṃ śrutaṃ bhavatīti pratijñātamekavijñānena sarvavijñānaṃ brahmaṇa ekasyaiva pāramārthye ghaṭate /
analyzed: nanu uta tam ādeśam aprākṣyaḥ yena aśratam śrutam bhavati iti pratijñātam eka vijñānena sarva vijñānam brahmaṇaḥ ekasya eva pāramārthye ghaṭate
translated: But it is promised We shall ask about that instruction by which what is not heard becomes heard, the knowledge of all by the knowledge of one is possible only if Brahman alone is real.

analyzed: na tu tad bhinnānām bahūnām pāramārthye
translated: Not if many different from that are real.

analyzed: tad prapañcasya apāramārthyam akāmena api svīkartavyam iti ced tatra āha eka iti
translated: If it is argued that the unreality of that world must be accepted even unwillingly, then he says ekena etc.

original: brahmaṇo nikhilajagadantarātmatvena nikhilajagatpradhānatayā nikhilasya ca taccharīratvena
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ nikhila jagat antarātma tvena nikhila jagat pradhāna tayā nikhilasya ca tad śarīra tvena
translated: Since Brahman is the inner self of the entire world, the principal of the entire world, and the entire world is its body,

original: tatprakārataikasvarūpatayā tasmin jñāte tadanantargataṃ kimapi jñātavyaṃ mukhyaṃ
analyzed: tad prakāra tā eka svarūpa tayā tasmin jñāte tad an antargatam kim api jñātavyam mukhyam
translated: and since it is of the nature of that, being of the same form as that, when that is known, nothing else remaining in that is to be known primarily,

original: nāvaśiṣyata iti ekavijñānena sarvavijñāvākyasyārtha iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: na avaśiṣyate iti eka vijñānena sarva vijñā vākyasya arthaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that by one cognition, the meaning of the statement all is known remains.

analyzed: ityādi iti
translated: Thus, etc.

original: niruktārthaparaiḥ śrutivacanaistanmūlopabṛṃhaṇasmṛtivacanaiśca brahmātmakatvena labdhasvarūpaḥ prapañca ityeva bodhyate /
analyzed: nirukta artha paraiḥ śruti vacanaiḥ tad mūla upabṛṃhaṇa smṛti vacanaiḥ ca brahma ātmaka tvena labdha svarūpaḥ prapañcaḥ iti eva bodhyate
translated: The world, whose nature is known as Brahman by the statements of the Veda with the meanings explained, and by the statements of Smriti which are based on it, is understood to be just Brahman.

original: na tu brahmaṇo vibhūtibhūtaḥ sa niṣidhyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: na tu brahmaṇaḥ vibhūti bhūtaḥ sa niṣidhyate iti arthaḥ
translated: But it is not that which is denied as being a manifestation of Brahman. This is the meaning.

analyzed: brahma ātmanā ātmalābhaḥ iti
translated: The attainment of the self in Brahman.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ lābhaḥ yasya iti bahuvrīhiḥ
translated: A bahuvrihi compound meaning that which has the attainment of the self.

analyzed: brahma abhinna antarātmanā prayojya sva rūpa lābhavān iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: having the attainment of the inherent nature which is not different from Brahman.

analyzed: brahma tā ātmalābhaḥ yam iti samasta pāṭhaḥ saṃbhāvya
translated: This compound Brahmatma-labha is possible.

original: tatra ca ātmano lābhaḥ ātmalābhaḥsvarūpasattā brahmatmatayābrahmatmakatvena ātmalābho yasyeti bahuvrīhiḥ /
analyzed: tatra ca ātmanaḥ lābhaḥ ātma lābhaḥ svarūpa sattā ātma lābhaḥ yasya iti bahuvrīhiḥ
translated: And there, the attainment of the self is the attainment of one's own nature. The attainment of the self in Brahman means that which has the attainment of the self in the form of Brahman, a bahuvrihi compound.

original: brahmāvibhūtibhūtasya prapañcasya na niṣedhaḥ kṛtaḥ śāstreṣviti nirūpitametāvatā // // //
analyzed: brahma a vibhūti bhūtasya prapañcasya na niṣedhaḥ kṛtaḥ śāstreṣu iti nirūpitam etāvatā
translated: It has been determined so far that the world, which is not a manifestation of Brahman, is not denied in the scriptures.

analyzed: tad niṣedhe samastasya mithyātvāt loka vedayoḥ
translated: In its denial, the entire world is false, according to the scriptures and the Vedas.

analyzed: vyavahārāḥ tu lupyeran tathā syāt brahma dhīḥ api
translated: But transactions would be destroyed, and so would the cognition of Brahman.

analyzed: atha prapañca niṣedhasya anupapanna tvāt api niṣedha para tayā iva āpātataḥ śruti vākyānām api ānyaparyam eva eṣṭavyam iti āśayavān āha tad niṣedha
translated: Now, since the denial of the world is not logically possible, even if the statements of the scriptures are provisionally accepted as having the purport of denial, other meanings must be accepted. With this intention, he says: That denial

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: prapañcaniṣedhe vivakṣite śāstravacanataḥ tattadarthaviśeṣapratipādanopādānādyarthāḥ sarve vyavahārā laukikā vaidikāśca lupyeranaprāmāṇikā
analyzed: prapañca niṣedhe vivakṣite śāstra vacanataḥ tad tad artha viśeṣa pratipādana upādāna ādi arthāḥ sarve vyavahārāḥ laukikāḥ vaidikāḥ ca lupyeran aprāmāṇikā
translated: When the denial of the world is intended, all transactions, both worldly and Vedic, which are based on the presentation of particular meanings by the statements of the scriptures, would be destroyed, would be invalid,

analyzed: visaṃvādinaḥ ca bhaveyuḥ
translated: and would be contradictory.

analyzed: sarvasya mithyātvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because everything is false.

original: nanu bhedavyavahārāṇāmaprāmāṇikatvamiṣṭameveti cettatrāhatatheti /🔽brahmabhinnasarvamithyātve brahmaviṣayakadhiya aupaniṣadyā apivilopo 'satyatā prasajyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: nanu bheda vyavahārāṇām aprāmāṇika tvam iṣṭam eva iti ced tatra āha tathā iti  brahma bhinna sarva mithyātve brahma viṣayaka dhiyaḥ aupaniṣadyāḥ satyatā prasajyate iti arthaḥ
translated: If it is argued that the invalidity of the transactions based on difference is accepted itself, then he says: Thus.🔽If everything is false, different from Brahman, the cognition of Brahman, even the Upanisadic, would be destroyed, falsity would result. This is the meaning.

analyzed: asatya kāraṇa janya tvāt asatya tvam asatya viṣaya tvam ca bhavet tasyāḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that it would be false, having a false object, because it is produced by a false cause.

analyzed: vyāvahārika satya tvāt mṛṣātve pi aviruddha tā
translated: Even if it is false, there is no contradiction due to being conventionally true.

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādeḥ iti matam prāk eva samadūduṣam
translated: The view that perception etc. is refuted has already been refuted.

original: nanu paramārthadṛṣṭyā brahmabhinnasya sarvasya mithyātve 'pi tataḥ prāk avidyātaḥ pramāṇaprameyavyavahārādi nirūhyata iti cettatrāhavyāvahāriketi
analyzed: nanu paramārtha dṛṣṭyā brahma bhinnasya sarvasya mithyātve pi tatas prāk avidyātaḥ pramāṇa prameya vyavahāra ādi nirūhyate iti ced tatra āha vyāvahārikā iti
translated: If it is argued that even though everything except Brahman is false from the standpoint of ultimate truth, the usage of pramāṇa, prameya etc. is to be inferred prior to that from ignorance, then he says:

analyzed: etad dūṣaṇa bhāgaḥ viluptaḥ
translated: This part of the criticism is lost.

original: vyāvahārikasattayā pramāṇaprameyavyavahāropapādane vyāvahārikapramāṇabhāvena śrutyādinā janitā parabrahmabuddhirapi bhavatabhimatā vyāvahārikārthamātragocarā 🔽bhavet /
analyzed: vyāvahārika sattayā pramāṇa prameya vyavahāra upapādane vyāvahārika pramāṇa bhāvena śruti ādinā janitā para brahma buddhiḥ api bhavat abhimatā vyāvahārika artha mātra gocarā  / bhavet
translated: In establishing the usage of pramāṇa and prameya by conventional existence, even the cognition of the supreme Brahman produced by Śruti etc. as conventional pramāṇa would be confined to mere conventional objects.

analyzed: nirviśeṣa brahma mātra pāramārthyasya api vyavahāra eka śaraṇa tvāt
translated: Because even the ultimate reality of Brahman alone without any distinctions is dependent solely on convention.

analyzed: tathā ca brahma mātra pāramārthyam api paramārtha sādhaka abhāvāt na sidhyet
translated: And in that case, even the ultimate reality of Brahman alone would not be established due to the absence of a means of establishing the ultimate.

original: etadviṣaye pūrvācāryaiḥ sūribhireva parākrāntaṃ nitarāmiti visamyate 'treti bodhyam // //
analyzed: etad viṣaye pūrva ācāryaiḥ sūribhiḥ eva parākrāntam nitarām iti visamyate tra iti bodhyam  /
translated: It should be understood that this topic has been thoroughly dealt with by the ancient teachers themselves, and it is repeated here.

analyzed: atas ca upaniṣad jāta brahma advaita dhita dhiyā jagat
translated: And therefore, by the thought of the oneness of Brahman born from the Upaniṣads, the world,

analyzed: na bādhyate vibhūti tvāt brahmaṇaḥ ca iti avasthitam
translated: The world is not contradicted, because it is the abundance of Brahman, as is established by the Vedanta.

analyzed: iti prapañcasya brahma vibhūti tva sthāpana pūrvakam advitīya śruti artha varṇanam
translated: Thus, having established the world as the abundance of Brahman, he describes the meaning of the non-dual scriptures.

analyzed: advitīya śruteḥ prapañca ābādhaka tva nirūpaṇam nigamayati atas ca iti
translated: He concludes the examination of the non-contradiction of the world by the non-dual scripture with the word ataśca (and for this reason).

original: brahmaṇo vibhūtitvācca jagadbrahmādvaitadhiyā na bādhyate /🔽savibhūtikasyaiva tasyādvitīyatvadhiya upaniṣatsiddhatvāt /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ vibhūti tvāt ca jagat brahma advaita dhiyā na bādhyate  sa vibhūtikasya eva tasya advitīya tva dhiyaḥ upaniṣad siddha tvāt
translated: And because the world is the abundance of Brahman, it is not contradicted by the idea of the non-duality of the world and Brahman.🔽Because it is established in the Upanishads that only that which has abundance is non-dual.
The word ca (and) indicates the inclusion of other reasons such as the establishment of the cognition that is not contradicted.

analyzed: yat vā castu arthe
translated: Or, the word ca (and) has the meaning of tu (but).

analyzed: samaḥ dhikaḥ vā bādhyate
translated: The equal or superior is contradicted.

analyzed: na tu jagat vibhūti bhūtam iti arthaḥ
translated: But the world, which is the abundance of Brahman, is not, is the meaning.

original: nanu sattve prapañcasya nāstīti pratyayaḥ katham /
analyzed: nanu sattve prapañcasya na asti iti pratyayaḥ katham
translated: But if the world exists, how can there be the idea that it does not exist?

original: asattve vā kathaṃ tasminnastīti pratyayo bhavet // //
analyzed: asattve vā katham tasmin asti iti pratyayaḥ bhavet
translated: Or, if it does not exist, how can there be the idea that it exists?

analyzed: prapañcasya advitīya śrutyāḥ bādhaḥ iti parapakṣaḥ nirastaḥ
translated: The opponent's view that the world is contradicted by the non-dual scripture is refuted.

original: atha tasya sadasadanirvacanīyatvamapi parābhimataṃ nirasituṃ vicāramupakramate nanu sattve iti /
analyzed: atha tasya sat asat anirvacanīya tvam api para abhimatam nirasitum vicāram upakramate nanu sattve iti
translated: Now, in order to refute even the non-determinate nature of existence and non-existence accepted by others, he begins the investigation with But how can existence...

original: sattve prapañcasya nāstīti bādhaviṣayatvaṃ kathaṃ ghaṭatetyākṣepo mādhyamikādīnām /
analyzed: sattve prapañcasya nā asti iti bādha viṣaya tvam katham ghaṭa tā iti ākṣepaḥ mādhyamika ādīnām
translated: The objection of the Mādhyamikas and others is: If the world exists, how can it be the object of negation, as in 'it does not exist'?

analyzed: atra pratīpakṣaḥ sāṅkhya ādīnām asattu eva iti
translated: Here, the counter-argument of the Sāṃkhyas and others is: If it does not exist...

original: asattve sadbuddhibodhyatvaṃ pratipannaṃ tasya kathaṃ ghaṭeteti // //
analyzed: asattve sat buddhi bodhya tvam pratipannam tasya katham ghaṭeta iti
translated: If it does not exist, how can it be understood by the cognition of existence that is accepted?

analyzed: sat asat tvam tathā ekasya viruddha tvāt asambhavi
translated: Existence and non-existence of the same thing is impossible due to contradiction.

analyzed: sat asat pratyaya prāpta viruddha dvandva saṅgame
translated: When there is a combination of contradictory pairs obtained by the notions of existence and non-existence,

analyzed: tayoḥ anyatara arthasya niścaya abhāva hetutaḥ  sat asat tvam prapañcasya jaināḥ tu pratipedire
translated: Because of the absence of certainty regarding the meaning of either of them,🔽The Jains accept the existence and non-existence of the world.

analyzed: nanu asti nāsti buddhi balāt sat asat tvam vācyam iti jaināḥ
translated: The Jains say that existence and non-existence should be stated due to the power of the notions of existence and non-existence.

analyzed: tatra āha sat asat tvam iti  viruddha dvayam asambhavat ekasmin na upagama arham iti yāvat
translated: To that, he says existence and non-existence...🔽A contradictory pair cannot reasonably be accepted in one thing.

analyzed: vicāra prasaktim āha sat asat iti
translated: He states the reason for the discussion with existence and non-existence...

analyzed: viruddha ākāra dvaya prasaṅge paraspara virodhāt ubhayasya anyatarasya ākārasya vā anirṇayāt hetoḥ vicāraḥ prāpta avasaraḥ iti yāvat
translated: When there is the contingency of two contradictory forms, due to mutual contradiction, there is uncertainty about both or either form, so the consideration of the reason has arrived at the appropriate occasion, that is, so far.

analyzed: atra vicāraḥ prakramyate eti śeṣa pūraṇena vākya arthaḥ vaktavyaḥ
translated: Here, the meaning of the sentence should be stated by supplying the remainder, that the consideration is being commenced.

analyzed: tatra ādau anaikāntya vādinām jainānām matam āha sadasatvam iti
translated: There, first, he states the opinion of the Jains, who advocate inconclusiveness, with existence and non-existence.

analyzed: pratīyamāna tvāt eva ekasmin sat asat tvayoḥ na virodhaḥ iti abhimānaḥ
translated: The idea is that there is no contradiction in existence and non-existence in one thing itself, because it is cognized.

analyzed: yat vā jaina mata anuvādaḥ sat asat pratyaya prāpta iti ārabhya jaināḥ tu pratijānataḥ ityantena
translated: Or, the statement of the Jain view begins with due to the attainment of the notions of existence and non-existence and ends with the Jains assert.

original: sadasattvayoḥ pratīyayormadhye ekasyaiva nirṇaye hetvabhāvādyathāpratīti prapañcasyobhayamevaiṣṭavyamiti janā āsthitā ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: sat asat tvayoḥ ekasya eva nirṇaye hetu abhāvāt yathāpratīti prapañcasya ubhayam eva eṣṭavyam iti janāḥ āsthitāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the people have accepted that both must be accepted of the world as it is cognized, because there is no reason for the determination of only one of the two, existence and non-existence, which are cognized.

original: niścayābhāvahetuta ityanena niścayahetvabhāvo vivakṣitaḥ /🔽pāṭhāntaraṃ vā saṃbhāvyate // // //
analyzed: niścaya abhāva hetutaḥ iti anena niścaya hetu abhāvaḥ vivakṣitaḥ  pāṭha antaram vā saṃbhāvyate
