translated: And like the talk of liberation in a dream, so is the talk of liberation from that,

original: tathaiva bhavato 'pīti vyartho mokṣāya te śramaḥ // //
analyzed: tathā eva pi iti vyarthaḥ mokṣāya te śramaḥ
translated: In the same way, for you also; so your effort for liberation is useless.

analyzed: prakāra antareṇa api vāde smin dūṣaṇam āha yathā iti
translated: He states the refutation of this doctrine in another way also: As, etc.

analyzed: tad vimukti gīḥ śuka ādeḥ mukti vāṇī
translated: The voice of liberation of parrots, etc.

analyzed: śuka ādibhiḥ api anadhigatā muktiḥ yuṣyābhiḥ prāpyā iti asambhavam
translated: Liberation is not attained even by parrots, etc., but is attained by you; this is impossible.

analyzed: svāpna kalpā eva sā bhavanti api
translated: It is like a dream even for you.

analyzed: tat vṛthā prayāsaḥ yuṣmākam iti arthaḥ  yathā teṣām abhūta eva purastāt ātma vidyayā
translated: The meaning is: your effort is in vain.🔽As for them, liberation was non-existent before, but is said to be existent through the knowledge of the self.

analyzed: muktiḥ bhūtā ucyate tadvat parastāt ātma vidyayā
translated: In the same way, liberation will be non-existent after, but is said to be existent through the knowledge of the self.

analyzed: abhāvinī eva sā mithyā bhāvinī iti apadiśyatām
translated: Let it be declared as non-existent, but falsely said to be existent.

analyzed: santi ca svapna dṛṣṭāni dṛṣṭānta vacanāni te
translated: And there are examples seen in dreams for you.

analyzed: mukti artha prayāsam parityajya muktiḥ na bhavitā iti eva sādhayatā iti āha yathā iti
translated: Abandoning the effort for liberation, he proves that liberation will not occur, saying as, etc.

analyzed: yathā adhyātma vidyayā śuka ādīnām bhūtā eva muktiḥ abhūtā iti ucyate
translated: As for parrots, etc., liberation which was non-existent before is said to be existent through the knowledge of the self.

original: tathā bhavatāṃ tataḥ paścādbhāvinyapi sā mithyā /
analyzed: tathā bhavatām tatas paścāt bhāvinī api sā mithyā
translated: In the same way, for you, it will be non-existent after, but is falsely said to be existent.

analyzed: na bhāvinī eva vastutas iti ucyatām iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: let it be said that it is not actually existent in the future.

analyzed: sāmarthya abhāvinī iti prācīna mudrita pāṭhaḥ tu na samanvitaḥ
translated: The old printed text sāmarthyābhaviṇī is not consistent.

analyzed: nanu madīya tattva jñāna niṣpadyamāna mukti mithyātvam katham iti atra āhasanti iti
translated: Now, how is the falsity of the liberation that is being produced from my true knowledge of reality? In this regard, he says santi (there are).

analyzed: bhavadīyam tattva jñānam na avidyā nivartakam tattva jñāna tvāt
translated: Your true knowledge does not remove ignorance, because it is true knowledge.

analyzed: svāpna tattva jñāna vat iti hi suvacam bhavat upadarśita diśā eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: It is well said that it is like the true knowledge in a dream, by the direction shown by you. This is the meaning.

analyzed: nanu nā idam aniṣṭam me yat muktiḥ na bhaviṣyati
translated: Now, this is not undesirable for me, that liberation will not occur.

original: ātmano nityamuktatvānnityasiddhaiva sā yataḥ // //🔽mukterabhāvitvaprasaṅgo 'smākamiṣṭa eveti śaṅkate nanu nedamiti /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ nitya mukta tvāt nitya siddhā eva sā yatas  mukteḥ abhāvi tva prasaṅgaḥ smākam iṣṭaḥ eva iti śaṅkate nanu na idam iti
translated: Because liberation is eternally accomplished, since the self is eternally liberated.🔽The occurrence of the undesirable consequence of the non-existence of liberation is indeed accepted by us. This is suspected in natu nedam.

analyzed: sāmuktiḥ
translated: The liberation is not there.

analyzed: tat idam śānti karma ādau vetāla āvāhanam bhavet
translated: This would be the invocation of the Vetala in the rites for peace, etc.

analyzed: yena evam sutarām vyarthaḥ brahma vidyā arjana śramaḥ  parihāsa mukhena pariharati tat idam iti
translated: By which, the effort to acquire the knowledge of Brahman is all the more futile.🔽He replies with a joke - tadivadam.

analyzed: bhavat pravṛtti viruddham bhavadīyam mukti abhāvi tva sādhanam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the proof of the non-existence of your liberation is contrary to your engagement.

analyzed: avidyā pratibaddha tvāt atha sā nitya satī api
translated: Or, because it is bound by ignorance, even though it is eternal and true,

original: asatīveti tadvyaktirvidyāphalamupeyate // //🔽hastasthameva hemādi vismṛtaṃ mṛgyate yathā /
analyzed: asatī iva iti tad vyaktiḥ vidyā phalam upeyate  hasta stham eva hema ādi vismṛtam mṛgyate yathā
translated: The manifestation of that [Self] as non-existent is accepted as the fruit of knowledge.🔽Just as gold, etc. in one's hand, forgotten, is sought,

analyzed: yathā tat eva hasta stham avagamya upaśāmyati  /
translated: Just as, having recognized that very [gold] in one's hand, one is pacified,

analyzed: tathā eva nitya siddha ātma sva rūpa anavabodhataḥ
translated: In the same way, due to the non-understanding of the eternally established nature of the Self,

analyzed: saṃsāriṇaḥ tathā bhāvaḥ vyajyate brahma vidyayā
translated: The state of being a transmigrating being is manifested by the knowledge of Brahman.

analyzed: atra parihāram śaṅkate paraḥ avidyā iti
translated: Here, the opponent raises a counter-argument: By the word 'ignorance'.

original: ayaṃ bhāvaḥ yadyapi muktirnityasiddhā brahmavidyayā notpādyā /
analyzed: ayam bhāvaḥ yadi api muktiḥ nitya siddhā brahma vidyayā na utpādyā
translated: The idea is this: Although liberation is eternally established and not produced by the knowledge of Brahman,

analyzed: athā api avidyā pratibaddhāyāḥ tirobhūtāyāḥ tasyāḥ abhivyakti arthe eva saphale brahma vidyā pariśramaḥ
translated: Nevertheless, the effort in the fruitless knowledge of Brahman is only for the manifestation of that [liberation], which is bound by ignorance and has become hidden.

original: sata evāprakāśamānatvenāsata iva sthitasyābhivyaktyarthaḥ prayatno yathā loke saphalo dṛṣṭastatheti // // // //
analyzed: sataḥ eva aprakāśamāna tvena asataḥ iva sthitasya abhivyakti arthaḥ prayatnaḥ yathā loke saphalaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ tathā iti
translated: Just as an effort is seen to be fruitful in the world for the manifestation of that which exists but remains as if non-existent due to not being manifest, in the same way [the effort in Brahman-knowledge is fruitful].

analyzed: hanta kā iyam abhivyaktiḥ yā vidyā phalam iṣyate
translated: Well then, what is this manifestation that is accepted as the fruit of knowledge?

analyzed: sva prakāśasya cit dhātoḥ yā svarūpa pade sthitā
translated: It is that which abides in the state of the intrinsic nature of the self-luminous essence of consciousness.

original: saṃvit kiṃ saiva kiṃ vāhaṃ brahmāsmītīti kīdṛśī /
analyzed: saṃvid kim sā eva kim vā aham brahma asmi iti iti kīdṛśī
translated: Is it mere consciousness? Or am I Brahman? What kind of [consciousness is it]?

analyzed: yadi sva rūpa saṃvid sā
translated: If it is the consciousness of one's own nature,

analyzed: nityā eva iti na tad phalam
translated: It is eternal, therefore it has no result.

analyzed: atra yadi api eka avidyā pakṣe śukasya brahma vidyayā eva avidyā pratibandha nivṛtteḥ anyadīya prayatna vaiphalyam sthitam
translated: Here, although in the view of one ignorance, it is established that due to the removal of the obstruction of ignorance by the Brahman knowledge of the parrot alone, the effort of others is futile,

analyzed: atha api dūṣaṇa antaram āha hanta ityādinā
translated: nevertheless, he states another fault with But if and so on.

analyzed: nānā vidyā pakṣa sādhāraṇam idam
translated: This is common to the view of many ignorances.

original: kimitarānapekṣaprakāśaikarūpasya cittattvasya svarūpameva vidyāsādhyābhiniṣpattiḥ /🔽pratyutāhaṃ brahmāsmīti vṛttidhīḥ sākṣātkārarūpetyarthaḥ /🔽brahmāsmītītyasyāgre vṛttidhīrityāhāryam /
analyzed: kim itara anapekṣa prakāśa eka rūpasya cit tattvasya svarūpam eva vidyā sādhya abhiniṣpattiḥ  pratyuta aham brahma asmi iti vṛtti dhīḥ sākṣātkāra rūpā iti arthaḥ  brahma asmi iti iti asya agre vṛtti dhīḥ iti āhāryam
translated: Is the manifestation of the nature of the mind, which is of the form of light independent of others, accomplished by Brahman knowledge?🔽Rather, the meaning is that the cognition of the state I am Brahman is of the form of direct experience.

original: iti kīdṛśīityevaṃ jijñāsitaprakārābrahmāsmītīti vṛttidhīriti vā pāṭhaḥ syāt /
analyzed: iti kīdṛśī iti evam jijñāsita prakārā brahma asmi iti iti vṛtti dhīḥ iti vā pāṭhaḥ syāt
translated: I am Brahman - before this, the reading should be the cognition of the state or the cognition of the state of 'I am Brahman'.

analyzed: aparaḥ itikāraḥ vikalpa samāptau
translated: The other iti is for the completion of the option.

analyzed: ādye kalpe dūṣaṇam ucyate yadi iti ardhena
translated: In the first case, the fault is stated with the half verse If and so on.

analyzed: atha brahma aham asmi iti saṃvittiḥ vyaktiḥ iṣyate
translated: If the cognition I am Brahman is accepted as the manifestation,

original: nanu te brahmavidyā sā saiva tasyāḥ phalaṃ katham // //
analyzed: nanu te brahma vidyā sā sā eva tasyāḥ phalam katham
translated: then is not that Brahman knowledge itself? How can that be the result of that?

analyzed: dvitīye dūṣaṇam ucyate atha iti
translated: In the second case, the fault is stated with If and so on.

analyzed: saṃvittiḥ sākṣātkāraḥ
translated: Cognition is direct experience.

original: na hi brahmavidyāsādhyaṃ prakāśāntaraṃ muktau bhavateṣyate /
analyzed: na hi brahma vidyā sādhyam prakāśa antaram muktau bhavatā iṣyate
translated: For it is not held that, in liberation, there is any other light to be accomplished by the knowledge of Brahman.

analyzed: tat sā eva tasyāḥ phalam iti vaktavyam
translated: It must be said that that itself is the fruit of that (knowledge).

analyzed: tat na saṃbhavi iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that that is not possible.

analyzed: kiñca sā tattvamasyādi vākya janyā bhavat mate
translated: Moreover, that (knowledge), according to your view, is produced by the sentences beginning with That art thou.

original: utpattimatyanityeti muktasyāpi bhayaṃ bhavet // //🔽atra kalpe dūṣaṇāntaraṃ cāhakiñceti /
analyzed: utpattimatī anityā iti muktasya api bhayam bhavet  atra kalpe dūṣaṇa antaram ca āha kiñca iti
translated: If it is produced, it is impermanent, so there would be fear even for the liberated one.

analyzed: nitya śuddha buddha mukta ātma svabhāvasya abhivyaktiḥ vṛtti rūpā ced tasyāḥ utpāda vināśa yogi tvāt tad nivṛttau punar avidyā samunmiṣet iti saṃsṛti bhaya anativṛtti prasaṅga  iti arthaḥ
translated: In this alternative, he states another fault: Moreover, if the manifestation of the nature of the self, which is eternal, pure, intelligent, and free, is in the form of activity, then, because it is associated with production and destruction, when that ceases, ignorance might manifest again. The meaning is that there would be the undesirable consequence of not overcoming the fear of worldly existence.

original: nanu pūrvāvidyāṃ vināśya vidyā svayamapi naśyati /🔽avidyānivṛttyā ca na punarbhavaprasaṅga iti cet /
analyzed: nanu pūrva avidyām vināśya vidyā svayam api naśyati  avidyā nivṛttyā ca na punarbhava prasaṅgaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that knowledge, having destroyed previous ignorance, itself perishes,🔽and that due to the cessation of ignorance, there is no possibility of rebirth,

original: atra brūmaḥ anādibhāvasya nāśāyogāt tattvasākṣātkāreṇāvidyāyā nātyantikocchedaḥ śakyakriyaḥ /
analyzed: atra brūmaḥ anādi bhāvasya nāśa ayogāt tattva sākṣātkāreṇa avidyāyāḥ na ātyantika ucchedaḥ śakya kriyaḥ
translated: we say in response that, because what has existed from beginningless time cannot be destroyed, the direct realization of reality cannot completely eradicate ignorance.

original: sāvaśeṣocchede tu sūkṣmarūpeṇāvasthitāyāstasyā abhivyakternivṛttau punaḥ sthūlatayonmeṣaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: sa avaśeṣa ucchede tu sūkṣma rūpeṇa avasthitāyāḥ tasyāḥ abhivyakteḥ nivṛttau punar sthūla tayā unmeṣa prasaṅgaḥ
translated: But if the destruction is incomplete, then, when the manifestation of that [ignorance] which remains in a subtle form is stopped, there is the possibility of its re-emergence in a gross form.

original: na cānādibhāvarūpāyā api mithyātvādeva ātyantikocchedaḥ kriyate vidyayeti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca anādi bhāva rūpāyāḥ api mithyātvāt eva ātyantika ucchedaḥ kriyate vidyayā iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that even that which has existed from beginningless time is destroyed completely by knowledge, because of its being false.

analyzed: tad mithyātve eva vigānāt
translated: Because that [ignorance] is known to be false itself.

analyzed: yukteḥ ābhāsa tvāt śāstrasya ca anya paryāyāt iti
translated: Because the reasoning is fallacious and the scripture has another meaning. This is the direction...

analyzed: api ca vyavahāra jñāḥ sati puṣkala kāraṇe
translated: Moreover, those who know usage say that when the complete cause is present,

original: kāryaṃ na jāyate yena tamāhuḥ pratibandhakam // //
analyzed: kāryam na jāyate yena tam āhuḥ pratibandhakam
translated: the effect does not arise due to something, they call that an obstruction.

original: iha kiṃ tadyadutpattumupakrāntaṃ svahetutaḥ /🔽avidyāpratibaddhatvādutpattiṃ na prapadyate // //
analyzed: iha kim tat yat utpattum upakrāntam sva hetutaḥ  avidyā pratibaddha tvāt utpattim na prapadyate
translated: Here, what is that which has begun to arise from its own cause?🔽Because it is obstructed by ignorance, it does not attain arising.

analyzed: na muktiḥ nitya siddha tvāt
translated: Not liberation, because it is eternally accomplished.

analyzed: na brahma asmi iti dhīḥ api  na hi brahmāyaha
translated: Not even the cognition I am Brahman.🔽For, in the case of one who is not Brahman,

analyzed: masmi iti saṃvid puṣkala kāraṇam
translated: the cognition I am Brahman is not the complete cause.

analyzed: saṃsāriṇaḥ tat āsti iti katham sā pratibadhyate
translated: Since that exists for the transmigrating soul, how is it obstructed?

analyzed: yatas sā kāraṇa abhāvāt idānīm na upajāyate
translated: Since it does not arise now due to the absence of a cause,

analyzed: na punar pratibaddha tvāt asthāne tena tat vacaḥ
translated: not again because of being obstructed, therefore that statement is in the wrong place.

analyzed: iti eka jīva vāde mukti artha pravṛtti vaiyarthya ādi nirūpaṇam
translated: Thus, the futility of activity for liberation etc. in the doctrine of one individual soul.

analyzed: atha avidyāyāḥ nitya mukta bhāva vyakti pratibandhaka tva vacanam api pareṣām anupapannam iti āha api ca iti
translated: Now, the statement that ignorance is the obstruction to the manifestation of the eternally liberated state is also not tenable for others. He says Moreover, etc.

analyzed: sati puṣkala kāraṇe kārya utpatteḥ vighaṭaka tvam hi pratibandhaka tvam
translated: For, being an obstruction means being a hindrance to the production of an effect when the complete set of causes is present.

analyzed: mukteḥ aniṣpādya tvāt tad pratibandhaka tvam avidyāyāḥ na ghaṭate
translated: Since liberation is not to be accomplished, the state of being an obstruction to it does not hold for ignorance.

original: saṃsāriṇaśca viṣayaprāvaṇyadasāyāṃ tattvasākṣātkārapuṣkalakāraṇasampattetevāsiddhyā tadanudaya iti na tatrāpi pratibandhakatvaṃ tasyā ghaṭata
analyzed: saṃsāriṇaḥ ca tattva sākṣātkāra puṣkala kāraṇa sampad tā itā iva asiddhyā tad anudaye iti na tatra api pratibandhaka tvam tasyāḥ ghaṭata
translated: And for the transmigrating soul, the non-arising of that [liberation] is due to the non-establishment of the complete set of causes for the direct realization of reality in the state of inclination towards objects. Thus, the state of being an obstruction to that [liberation] is not tenable even there.

analyzed: iti arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: saṃvidaḥ puṣkala kāraṇam iti tatpuruṣaḥ
translated: The complete set of causes for consciousness is a tatpurusa compound.

original: siddhānte tu vidyāprāgabhāvarūpāyā avidyāyā na vidyāpratibandhakatvam /
analyzed: siddhānte tu vidyā prāgabhāva rūpāyāḥ avidyāyāḥ na vidyā pratibandhaka tvam
translated: But in the established conclusion, ignorance, which is the prior absence of knowledge, is not an obstruction to knowledge.

analyzed: karmaṇaḥ tu vidyā anutpatti prayojakasya niṣkāma karmabhiḥ nirāse sva kāraṇāt vidyā niṣpattiḥ
translated: But the removal of action, which is the cause of the non-arising of knowledge, by disinterested actions leads to the arising of knowledge from its own cause.

original: vidyāmāhātmyācca bandhakakarmanivṛttau karmaṇā saṅkucitaprasaraṇasya svābhāvikamasaṅkucitaṃ prasaraṇaṃ dharmabhūtajñānasya sadā muktāviti viśeṣo
analyzed: vidyā māhātmyāt ca bandhaka karma nivṛttau karmaṇā saṅkucita prasaraṇasya svābhāvikam asaṅkucitam prasaraṇam dharma bhūta jñānasya sadā muktau iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: And by the greatness of knowledge, when the binding karma ceases, the natural unrestricted expansion of the intrinsically restricted expansion of karma is in the eternal liberation of the knowledge that is the essence of Dharma. This distinction

analyzed: bodhyaḥ
translated: should be understood.

original: atra pare pratyavatiṣṭheran nanvasmanmate 'pi vastutattvāviśadaprakāśakarī nānābhramaheturavidyānādiriṣyate /
analyzed: atra pare pratyavatiṣṭheran nanu asmad mate vastu tattva a viśada prakāśa karī nānā bhrama hetuḥ avidyā anādiḥ iṣyate
translated: Here, others may object: Even in our view, ignorance, which causes various delusions by not clearly illuminating the truth of reality, is accepted as beginningless.

original: vidyayā tannivṛttau ca svābhāviko viśadāvabhāsaḥ /🔽viśadaprakāśapratirodhakaratvādeva ca pratibandhakatvavācoyuktistasyā iti /
analyzed: vidyayā tad nivṛttau ca svābhāvikaḥ viśada avabhāsaḥ  viśada prakāśa pratirodha kara tvāt eva ca pratibandhaka tva vācoyuktiḥ tasyāḥ iti
translated: And when it ceases due to knowledge, there is the natural clear manifestation.🔽And the expression 'obstructive' is used precisely because it obstructs the clear manifestation.

analyzed: tān prati brūmaḥ viśada prakāśa pratirodhaka tvam kim tat utpatti nirodhaka tvam
translated: To them we reply: Is the obstruction of clear manifestation the obstruction of its arising?

analyzed: uta aho tad nivṛtti kara tvam
translated: Or is it the cause of its cessation?

original: brahmasvarūpabhinnatve viśadaprakāśasya brahmaṇaḥ saviśeṣatvaprasaṅgāttadabhinnatve vācye 'nutpādyatvādeva tasya tatpratirodhakatvāyogānnādyaḥ 🔽kalpaḥ /
analyzed: brahma svarūpa bhinnatve viśada prakāśasya brahmaṇaḥ saviśeṣa tva prasaṅgāt tad abhinnatve vācye nutpādya tvāt eva tasya tad pratirodhaka tva ayogāt na ādyaḥ  kalpaḥ
translated: If the clear manifestation is different from the nature of Brahman, then Brahman would have a distinguishing feature. If it is said to be non-different from that, then the first option is not possible, because it cannot obstruct that due to its non-producibility itself.

analyzed: dvitīye ca brahma svarūpasya eva nivṛtti prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And in the second, there would be the consequence of the cessation of Brahman's nature itself.

analyzed: vaiśadyam eva nivartate
translated: Only the clarity ceases.

original: prakāśastvanuvartata iti ca nirviśeṣavādinā vaktuṃ na śakyate /
analyzed: prakāśaḥ tu anuvartate iti ca nirviśeṣa vādinā vaktum na śakyate
translated: But the light continues. This cannot be said by one who maintains that there is no difference.

original: kiñca viśadaprakāśapratirodhikāyāṃ satyāmavidyāyāṃ kathaṃ sākṣātkāro bhavet /
analyzed: kiñca viśada prakāśa pratirodhikāyām satyām avidyāyām katham sākṣātkāraḥ bhavet
translated: Moreover, when there is ignorance, which obstructs clear light, how can there be direct perception?

analyzed: saḥ pi aviśadaḥ ced prāthamika śrāvaṇa jñānasya iva avidyā nivartaka tva ayogaḥ  kiñca avidyā nivṛttau viśada sākṣātkāraḥ
translated: If that too is unclear, then like the initial auditory cognition, it cannot remove ignorance.🔽Moreover, when ignorance ceases, there is clear direct perception.

analyzed: tena eva ca avidyā nivṛttiḥ iti anyonya āśrayaḥ
translated: And by that alone there is cessation of ignorance. This is mutual dependence.

analyzed: kiñca avidyā nivṛtti anantara bāvinaḥ viśada anubhavasya prāk asattve mukteḥ anitya tvam
translated: Moreover, if the clear experience that exists after the cessation of ignorance did not exist before, then liberation would be impermanent.

original: sattve ca saṃsārānupapattiḥ saṃsārānupapattiḥ prasajyate /🔽naca nivṛttāvidyatvameva svarūpaprakāśasya svarūpaprakāśasya vaiśadyamiti vācyam /
analyzed: sattve ca saṃsāra anupapattiḥ saṃsāra anupapattiḥ prasajyate  naca nivṛtta avidyā tvam eva sva rūpa prakāśasya sva rūpa prakāśasya vaiśadyam iti vācyam
translated: And if it did exist, then worldly existence would be impossible. The impossibility of worldly existence would follow.🔽And it cannot be said that the cessation of ignorance itself is the clarity of the light of one's own nature.

original: svaprakāśamātravapuṣi sadā vidyotamāne nirviśeṣe cinmātre brahmaṇi avidyānvayāyogātpragapi vaiśadyasyaivopagantavyatvāt /
analyzed: sva prakāśa mātra vapuṣi sadā vidyotamāne nirviśeṣe cit mātre brahmaṇi avidyā anvaya ayogāt prak api vaiśadyasya eva upagantavya tvāt
translated: For in Brahman, the pure consciousness which is the essence of self-luminous light, which always shines without difference, it is not possible for ignorance to be related, and therefore clarity must be accepted even before.

original: durghaṭatvāttatra padamañcatyavidyeti cettarhi tata eva muktāvapyavidyānvayaprasaktiriti muktasyāpi bhayaṃ bhavedeveti // // //
analyzed: durghaṭa tvāt tatra padam añcati avidyā iti ced tarhi tatas eva muktau api avidyā anvaya prasaktiḥ iti muktasya api bhayam bhavet eva iti
translated: If it be said that there is no ignorance there because it is impossible, then, on that very account, there would be a connection of ignorance even in liberation; and so there would be fear even for the liberated.

analyzed: kiñca ekaḥ jīvaḥ iti etat vastu sthityā na yujyate
translated: Moreover, this doctrine that there is one individual soul is not tenable as a fact.

analyzed: avidyā tad samāśleṣa jīva tva ādī mṛṣā hi te
translated: For the states of being an individual soul, etc., are false, being due to Nescience and its concomitants.

analyzed: eka jīva vāde dūṣaṇāni uktāni  atha tasya upalambha bādhita tvam āha kiñca ekaḥ iti
translated: The objections to the doctrine of one individual soul have been stated.

analyzed: ekaḥ vā jīvaḥ parama arthaḥ ūna iṣyate
translated: Now, he states that it is contradicted by perception: Moreover, one individual soul is not accepted as real.

analyzed: mithyāvidyā kalpita tvena jīva bhāvasya mithyātvāt
translated: For the state of being an individual soul is false, being imagined by false Nescience.

original: tathā ca mithyābhūtasyaikasyānekasya vā jīvasyopagame na viśeṣo vinābhiniveśādityarthaḥ // //
analyzed: tathā ca mithyābhūtasya ekasya anekasya vā jīvasya upagame na viśeṣaḥ vinā abhiniveśāt iti arthaḥ
translated: And thus, whether one or many individual souls are accepted as false, there is no difference without attachment.

analyzed: prātibhāsikam eka tvam pratibhāsa parāhatam
translated: The apparent oneness is contradicted by appearance,

analyzed: yatas naḥ pratibhāsante saṃsarantaḥ sahasraśas
translated: since we perceive thousands of them transmigrating.

analyzed: ekaḥ jīvaḥ iti kim ekasya eva pratibhāsāt upagamyate
translated: Is it accepted that there is one individual soul because it appears as such to one?

original: āhosvinnānātvena bhāsamānasyāpi tasya yuktyaikatvaṃ niṣkṛṣyata iti vikalpamabhipretyādyaṃ kalpaṃ dūṣayatiprādibhāsikamiti /
analyzed: āhosvit nānātvena bhāsamānasya api tasya yuktyā ekatvam niṣkṛṣyate iti vikalpam abhipretya ādyam kalpam dūṣayati prādibhāsikam iti
translated: Or, is it that, even though it appears as diverse, its unity is extracted by reasoning? With this doubt in mind, he criticizes the first view, saying What appears as diverse, etc.

analyzed: spaṣṭaḥ ūrthaḥ
translated: The meaning is clear.

analyzed: āsaṃsāra samucchedam vyavahārāḥ ca tad kṛtāḥ
translated: The worldly conventions produced by that are not contradicted until the end of saṃsāra,

analyzed: abādhitāḥ pratīyante svapna vṛtta vilakṣaṇāḥ
translated: and are perceived as unlike the events in a dream.

original: nānājīvabhānasya na vyavahāhakāla eva bādhyatvaṃ śuktirūpyāderivetyāhaāsaṃsāreti /
analyzed: nānā jīva bhānasya na vyavahāha kāle eva bādhya tvam śukti rūpya ādeḥ iva iti āha āsaṃsāra iti
translated: He says that the appearance of many jīvas is not contradicted even during the time of worldly conventions, like the silver in a shell.

analyzed: tad kṛtāḥ jīva bheda prayojyāḥ
translated: Produced by that means prompted by the diversity of jīvas.

analyzed: svapna vṛtta vilakṣaṇāḥ svāpna artha vyavahāra vilakṣaṇāḥ
translated: Unlike the events in a dream means unlike the worldly conventions of dream objects.

original: ayamāśayaḥyathā svāpnārthavyavahārāṇāṃ svapna evāsattvaṃ pāścātyabādhānniścīyate vyavahāradaśāyāmeva /
analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ yathā svāpna artha vyavahārāṇām svapne eva asattvam pāścātya bādhāt niścīyate vyavahāra daśāyām eva
translated: The idea is this: Just as the worldly conventions of dream objects are ascertained to be unreal only in the dream itself by subsequent contradiction,

analyzed: nā evam tadā eva jīva bheda prayukta vyavahāra bhedānām bādhaḥ niścitaḥ
translated: so the diversity of worldly conventions prompted by the diversity of jīvas is not ascertained to be contradicted at that very time.

original: kintvanyajīvakṛtasyopakārasyāpakārasya vā sattvapratītyaiva āprājñādābālagopālaṃ tadanuguṇapravṛttisaṃrambho dṛśyate 'nuvartamāna āpralayāt
analyzed: kintu anya jīva kṛtasya upakārasya apakārasya vā sattva pratītyā eva ā prājñāt ā bālagopālam tad anuguṇa pravṛtti saṃrambhaḥ dṛśyate nuvartamānaḥ ā pralayāt
translated: But the existence of help or harm done by another living being is seen to be inferred only from the existence of the living being, and the activity and effort in accordance with that are seen to continue until the dissolution of the world.

analyzed: vyavahāra kāle bādhya tvāt ca jīva bhedasya vyāvahārika tvam eva para prakriyayā api
translated: And because the difference of living beings is not contradicted at the time of worldly usage, it is only conventional even according to the opponent's view.

analyzed: na prātibhāsika tvam
translated: It is not merely illusory.

analyzed: jīva bhedaḥ mithyā pratibhāsamāna tvāt svāpna puṃs bheda vat iti anumānam ca vyavahāra daśā bādhya tvena sa upādhikam
translated: And the inference that the difference of living beings is false because it appears falsely, like the difference of men in a dream, is fallacious because it is contradicted by the state of worldly usage.

analyzed: tathā ca sūtram vaidharmyāt ca na svapna ādi vat iti iti
translated: And thus the aphorism: And because of dissimilarity, it is not like a dream, etc.

analyzed: tena yauktikam ekatvam api yukti parāhatam
translated: Therefore, even the logically established oneness is refuted by logic.
The contradictory activities inferred from the difference of activity,

analyzed: tad tad sva ātma vat anye śakya nihnavāḥ
translated: are undeniable for other embodied beings also, like one's own self.

analyzed: uktena eva hetunā yauktika ekatva niṣkarṣam api nirākaroti tena iti
translated: With the same reason, he refutes even the conclusion of logical oneness with Therefore.

analyzed: tena jīva bhedasya vyavahāra kāla ābādhena
translated: By that, by the non-contradiction of the difference of living beings at the time of worldly usage.

analyzed: sarve jīvāḥ aham eva jīva tvāt aham iva
translated: All living beings are indeed myself, because of being living beings, like myself.

analyzed: sarvāṇi śarīrāṇi mayā eva ātmavanti śarīra tvāt mad śarīra vat iti jīva aikya yuktiḥ jīva bheda sādhaka yukti parāhatā iti arthaḥ
translated: All bodies are possessed of self by me, because they are bodies, like my body. The reasoning of the oneness of the individual soul is defeated by the reasoning establishing the difference of the individual souls. This is the meaning.

analyzed: jīva bheda yukteḥ prābalyam ca vyavahāra abhādhya viṣaya tvāt upalambha ānuguṇyāt ca iti bodhyam
translated: And the superiority of the reasoning of the difference of the individual souls should be understood because it is the subject of the study of worldly usage and because it is in conformity with perception.

analyzed: nanu kā sā jīva nānātva yuktiḥ
translated: But what is that reasoning of the plurality of individual souls?

analyzed: tām āha pravṛtti bheda iti
translated: He states that as the difference in activity.

analyzed: tad tad deha gata vilakṣaṇa pravṛtti bheda anumitāḥ tad tad anuguṇa viruddha jñāna saṅkalpa prayatnavantaḥ
translated: The individual souls possessing knowledge, volition, and effort that are respectively in conformity with and opposed to that and that, are inferred from the difference in activity that is different in each body.

original: 'nye dehino 'pi sa sa svātmeva svaśarīrapravṛttyanuguṇajñānādimān pratyātmasiddho
analyzed: dehinaḥ pi sa sa sva ātmā iva sva śarīra pravṛtti anuguṇa jñāna ādimān pratyātma siddhaḥ
translated: He is like his own self, possessing knowledge, etc. that is in conformity with the activity of his own body. This is established for each individual self.

analyzed: na nihnotu śakyante iti arthaḥ
translated: They cannot be denied. This is the meaning.

analyzed: miti vṛtti grahaṇam saṅkalpasya api upalakṣaṇam
translated: The mention of activity is a reference to volition also.

original: paraśarīrāṇisātmakāni ceṣṭāvattvāt svaśarīravaditi sātmakatve 'numite tadātmanāṃ svātmabhedaḥ pariśeṣāt sidhyati /
analyzed: para śarīrāṇi sātmakāni ceṣṭāvat tvāt sva śarīra vat iti sātmaka tve numite tad ātmanām sva ātma bhedaḥ pariśeṣāt sidhyati
translated: Other bodies are possessed of self because they are active, like my own body. When possession of self is inferred, the difference of those selves from one's own self is established by elimination.

analyzed: para śarīra pravṛtti hetu bhūta saṅkalpa prayatnasya sva asamaveta tve sati guṇa tvāt sva bhinna samaveta tva anumānāt
translated: Because the volition and effort that are the cause of activity in another's body are qualities, being not-inseparable from the self, the inference is that they are inseparable from what is different from the self.

original: svāsamavetatvaṃ ca tasya svasya tadā bhinnasaṅkalpapravṛttimattvādeva suniśceyamiti bodhyam // //🔽yathānumeyādvahnyāderarā
analyzed: sva asamaveta tvam ca tasya svasya tadā bhinna saṅkalpa pravṛttimat tvāt eva su niśceyam iti bodhyam  / yathā anumeyāt vahni ādeḥ arā
translated: And it should be understood that the fact of their being not-inseparable from the self is well ascertained just by the fact that the self has volition and activity different from that.

analyzed: numānāḥ vilakṣaṇāḥ  pratyakṣam te kṣyante
translated: Just as the fires seen at the time of grasping the pervasion are different from the inferable fire,

analyzed: tathā anyebhyaḥ jīvebhyaḥ na pṛthak katham
translated: so the perceptions of others' bodies are not different from the other souls.🔽The perceptions of others' bodies are not different from the other souls.

analyzed: sādhyānām parātmanām nidarśanībhūta sva ātma bhinna tve nidarśanam pradarśayati yathā iti
translated: In order to show the example of the probandum, the other selves, different from the exemplified self, he says just as and so on.

original: ānumānāḥ anumānaprayojakāḥ sapakṣadṛṣṭāḥ vahnayo 'numeyātparvatīyavahneryathā bhinnāḥ vyāptigrahaṇakāle 'dhyakṣitāḥ /
analyzed: ānumānāḥ anumāna prayojakāḥ sapakṣa dṛṣṭāḥ vahnayaḥ numeyāt parvatīya vahneḥ yathā bhinnāḥ vyāpti grahaṇa kāle dhyakṣitāḥ
translated: The fires seen at the time of grasping the pervasion are different from the inferable mountain fire, just as the fires seen at the time of grasping the pervasion are different from the inferable mountain fire.

analyzed: tathā anumeyebhyaḥ para deha stha ātmabhyaḥ śarīra pravṛtti cetana sahkalpa prayatna pūrvakatva vyāpti graha kāle
translated: In the same way, at the time of grasping the pervasion of the body's activity being preceded by volition and effort of the conscious self, which is the probandum, different from the inferable self in another body,

analyzed: gṛhītam tvadīya ātma svarūpam tvad śarīra pravṛtti hetu saṅkalpa ādimat bhinnatvena kutas na pratyakṣam
translated: How is it that the form of your soul, which is grasped, is not perceived by perception as different from the intention etc. which are the cause of the activity of your body?

analyzed: api tu pratyakṣam eva iti yāvat
translated: Rather, it is indeed perceived.

analyzed: jīvānām aikya sādhanam vahnīnām aikya sādhana vat aprayojakam upalambha bādhitam ca iti hārdam
translated: The proof of the oneness of the individual souls is as unavailing as the proof of the oneness of the fires. And it is contradicted by perception. This is the heart of the matter.

analyzed: na ced ceṣṭā viśeṣeṇa paraḥ boddhā anumīyate
translated: If the other [soul] is not inferred from the particular activities [of the body],

analyzed: vyavahāraḥ sarvaḥ laukika vaidikaḥ
translated: all worldly and Vedic usage would be lost.
The proof regarding the supreme Self has been stated.

analyzed: tad anupagame bādhakam api āha na ced iti
translated: In the absence of that [proof], there is also a refutation [of the non-existence of the supreme Self], which is stated with If not...

original: paradeheṣu parātmanaśceṣṭāviśeṣairanukūlapratikūlodāsīnānūhitvaiva hi tattadanuguṇā vyavahārāḥ dṛṣṭā loke /
analyzed: para deheṣu para ātmanaḥ ceṣṭā viśeṣaiḥ anukūla pratikūla udāsīna an ūhitvā eva hi tad tad anuguṇāḥ vyavahārāḥ dṛṣṭāḥ loke
translated: In the bodies of others, the existence of the supreme Self as the experiencer of pleasure, pain, and indifference, which are in accordance with those [activities], is seen in the world.

analyzed: jīva bheda prayuktāḥ eva ca adhikāri anadhikāri vibhāga ādi vyavahārāḥ śāstrīyāḥ dṛṣṭāḥ
translated: And the distinctions of those eligible and not eligible, etc. based on the difference of individual souls are seen in the scriptures.

original: teṣāmuparodhaḥ prasajyate jīvabhedānupagama iti bhāvaḥ // //🔽na caupādhikabhedena meyamātṛvibhāgadhīḥ /
analyzed: teṣām uparodhaḥ prasajyate jīva bheda anupagamaḥ iti bhāvaḥ 🔽na ca aupādhika bhedena meya mātṛ vibhāga dhīḥ
translated: The contradiction of those [distinctions] arises if the difference of individual souls is not accepted. This is the idea.🔽The idea of the distinction of the object of knowledge and the knower based on the difference of adjuncts,

analyzed: sva śarīre pi tad prapteḥ śiraḥ pāṇi ādi bhedataḥ
translated: Because of the difference of head, hands, etc., even in one's own body, that [difference] is attained.

analyzed: nanu saṃvid mātram ekam eva nānā upādhi yogāt nānā jīva tayā bhāti
translated: But consciousness alone is one only, which appears as many individual souls due to the connection with various limiting adjuncts.

analyzed: aupādhika jīva bheda prayuktaḥ eva vyavahāra bhedaḥ
translated: The difference in usage is indeed caused by the difference in individual souls due to limiting adjuncts.

analyzed: svabhāva asaṅkaraḥ ca
translated: And there is no confusion in the nature [of consciousness].

analyzed: upādhi bhedaḥ pi tava iti āśaṅkām anūtyā pariharati na ca aupādhika iti
translated: The difference in limiting adjuncts is also imagined by you. Anticipating this doubt, he answers with And the difference due to limiting adjuncts is not tenable.
The explanation of the division of objects of knowledge is a relevant digression for the purpose of illustration.

analyzed: aupādhika bhedena vyavasthā upagame śiraḥ pāṇi pāda upādhi bhedena api tad tad avacchinna citaḥ bheda prasaṅgaḥ
translated: If you accept the distinction based on the difference in limiting adjuncts, then there would be the undesirable consequence of the difference of consciousness restricted by the difference in limiting adjuncts such as head, hands, and feet.

original: tathā ca pāde me vedanā /🔽śirasi sukhamityādipratisandhānānupattiriti yāvat // //🔽tayathā tatra śiraḥpāṇipādādau vedanodaye /
analyzed: tathā ca pāde me vedanā  śirasi sukham ityādi pratisandhāna anupattiḥ iti yāvat  tatra śiraḥ pāṇi pāda ādau vedanā udaye
translated: And in that case, there would be no recollection such as I have pain in the foot🔽I have pleasure in the head, and so on. This is the meaning.

analyzed: anusandhānam eka tve
translated: Just as there is recollection of the arising of pain in the head, hands, feet, etc.,🔽if there is oneness,

analyzed: tathā sarvatra te bhavet
translated: in the same way, it would be so everywhere for you.

analyzed: nanu upādhi bhede pi abhedāt citaḥ pratisandhānam iti ced tatra āha tathā iti
translated: If it is argued that there is recollection of consciousness due to non-difference even in the difference of limiting adjuncts, he says In the same way there.

analyzed: tathā iti aniṣṭa samuccaya arthaḥ
translated: In the same way means undesirable consequence.

analyzed: yathā iti vā syāt
translated: Or yathā (if) may be there.

analyzed: vastutas sarva śarīreṣu citaḥ aikyāt sarva gata sukha ādi pratisandhāna prasaṅgaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in reality, due to the oneness of consciousness in all bodies, there would be the undesirable consequence of the recollection of happiness etc. that is all-pervading.

analyzed: na ca vā ātma bhedaka tvam
translated: And the difference of bodies itself is not the cause of the difference of the self.

analyzed: nanu kara caraṇa ādi bhedasya iti vācyam
translated: But it should not be said that it is the difference of hands, feet, etc.

analyzed: saubhari ādau śarīra bhede pi pratisandhānasya dṛṣṭa tvāt tasya api bhedaka tva ayogāt
translated: Because in the case of Saubhari and others, even with the difference of bodies, there is recollection, and because that (difference of hands, feet, etc.) cannot be the cause of difference.

analyzed: naca tad tad puruṣīya karma adhīna dehasya eva tad tad bhoga avacchedak tvam iti vyavasthā
translated: And it cannot be argued that the body, which is dependent on the karma of each individual person, is only the means of experiencing that (happiness, etc.).

analyzed: saubhari ādeḥ yugapad nānā deha yogaḥ tad tarma kṛtaḥ eva
translated: Even the simultaneous connection of Saubhari and others with many bodies is only due to his karma.

analyzed: na tu asmad ādeḥ tathā iti vācyam
translated: It cannot be said that it is not so in the case of us (ordinary people).

analyzed: aupādhika ātma bheda vāde prati karma vyavasthāyāḥ api durghaṭa tvāt
translated: Because even the arrangement of karma for each individual is difficult to explain in the doctrine of the difference of the self due to adjuncts.

analyzed: upādheḥ tadīya tvam tad karmaṇā
translated: The adjunct belongs to him (the self) by his karma.

analyzed: upādhi vyavasthayā eva ca tad karma vyavasthitiḥ iti paraspara āśrayāt ca iti diś
translated: And the arrangement of his karma is only by the arrangement of the adjuncts. Thus, there is mutual dependence. This is the direction.

analyzed: atas jīva bhedena eva vāstavena bhoga ādi sāṅkaryam parihāryam iti āśayaḥ
translated: Therefore, the intended meaning is that the confusion of experience, etc. should be avoided only by the real difference of individual souls.

analyzed: prāyaṇāt naraka kleśāt prasūti vyasanāt api
translated: From death, from the suffering of hell, and also from the calamity of birth,

analyzed: cira ativṛttāḥ prāc janma bhogāḥ na smṛti gocarāḥ
translated: The experiences of previous births, long past, are not within the range of memory.

original: nanu śarīrabhede 'pyātmaikyātpratisandhāne janmāntare 'nubhūtasyāpi janmāntare pratisandhānaṃ syādityatrāhaprāyaṇāditi /
analyzed: nanu śarīrabhede pi ātma aikyāt pratisandhāne janmāntare nu bhūtasya api janmāntare pratisandhānam syāt iti atra āha prāyaṇāt iti
translated: But even with the difference of bodies, there would be remembrance in another birth of what was experienced in a previous birth, due to the oneness of the self. To this he says 'at death'.

analyzed: prabala duḥkha anubhavasya saṃskāra pramoṣaka tvam dṛṣṭam loke prabala jvara ādi arditasya adhīta vismaraṇa ādinā
translated: In the world, it is seen that the strong experience of pain destroys the impressions, as in the case of one afflicted by strong fever, etc., forgetting what was studied, etc.

original: janmabhede ca maraṇanarakagarbhavāsajanmakālaprabhavakleśabāhulyena saṃskāravināśātpūrvajanmānubhūtasmaraṇaṃ janmāntare ca jāyata ityarthaḥ
analyzed: janma bhede ca maraṇa naraka garbha vāsa janma kāla prabhava kleśa bāhulyena saṃskāra vināśāt pūrva janma anubhūta smaraṇam janmāntare ca jāyate iti arthaḥ
translated: And due to the abundance of suffering arising from death, hell, womb, and birth at the time of birth, the impressions are destroyed, so the memory of what was experienced in a previous birth does not occur in another birth. This is the meaning.

analyzed: kāla dairghyasya api saṃskāra pramoṣaka tvam abhipretya uktam cira ativṛttāḥ iti
translated: With the intention that even the length of time destroys the impressions, it is said 'long past'.

original: jīvanādṛṣṭabalāttu saṃskāraviśeṣasyāvinaṣṭatvaṃ jātamātra udbhūtatvaṃ ca kalpyate /
analyzed: jīvana adṛṣṭa balāt tu saṃskāra viśeṣasya avinaṣṭa tvam jāta mātre udbhūta tvam ca kalpyate
translated: But due to the power of the unseen force of life, the special impression is considered to be undestroyed and to arise as manifest as soon as one is born.

analyzed: keṣāñcid tu puṇya atiśayena saṃskāra apramoṣāt pūrva janma ādya vismaraṇam api loka śāstra sampratipannam eva iti bodhyam  /
translated: But it should be understood that for some, due to the non-destruction of impressions by the excess of merit, the non-forgetting of previous births, etc. is accepted by both the world and the scriptures.

analyzed: yugapad jāyamāneṣu sukha dukha ādiṣu sphuṭaḥ
translated: In the case of simultaneous... ... happiness, sorrow, etc., there is a clear...

analyzed: āśraya asaṅkaraḥ tatra katham aikārthya vibhramaḥ
translated: How can there be confusion about oneness in the absence of confusion about the substratum?

analyzed: iti eka avidyā kalpita eka jīva vāda nirāsaḥ
translated: Thus ends the refutation of the doctrine of one soul imagined by one ignorance.

analyzed: yugapad iti
translated: Simultaneously,

original: ekakṣaṇa eva jāyamāneṣu nānāsukhaduḥkhānubhaveṣu kāladairghyādisaṃskārapramoṣakavirahe 'pi asmaraṇādi ātmanāmasaṅkarāt anakyādeva vyavasthāpyam
analyzed: eka kṣaṇe eva jāyamāneṣu nānā sukha duḥkha anubhaveṣu kāla dairghya ādi saṃskāra pramoṣaka virahe pi asmaraṇa ādi ātmanām asaṅkarāt an akyāt eva vyavasthāpyam
translated: in the case of the experience of various happinesses and sorrows arising in one moment alone, even in the absence of the loss of impressions due to the absence of the long duration of time, etc., the arrangement is to be established by the non-confusion of the souls themselves due to non-remembrance, etc.

analyzed: tathā ca aikātmya dhiyaḥ bhrānti rūpāyāḥ api na udaya avasaraḥ
translated: And thus there is no opportunity for the appearance of the form of delusion in the form of the cognition of oneness.

analyzed: ātma bhedasya eva sphuṭa pratibhānāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the difference of the souls itself appears clearly.

analyzed: ekam eka avidyā kalpita eka jīva vāde dūṣaṇāni prapañcitāni  na ca prātisvika avidyā kalpita sva sva dṛśyakaiḥ
translated: The objections to the doctrine of one soul imagined by one ignorance have been elaborated.

analyzed: jīvaiḥ anekaiḥ api eṣā lokayātrā upapadyate
translated: And this worldly life is not possible even for many individual souls imagined by individual ignorances,🔽who are seen by each one,

analyzed: para vārttā anabhijñāḥ te sva sva svapna eka darśinaḥ
translated: being ignorant of the affairs of others, seeing only their own dreams,

analyzed: katham pravartayeyuḥ tām saṅga ādi eka nibandhanām
translated: how can they engage in that which is based on one thing, such as attachment?

analyzed: nānā vidyā kalpita nānā jīva vādam api dūṣayati na ca iti
translated: He also refutes the doctrine of many souls imagined by many ignorances with And this.

analyzed: avidyā kalpitāḥ citaḥ nānā jīṃva bhedāḥ
translated: The various individual souls are imagined by ignorance.

original: te ca svasvāvidyākalpitaṃ padārthajātaṃ paśyanti pṛthak pṛthak svapna iva /
analyzed: te ca sva sva avidyā kalpitam padārtha jātam paśyanti pṛthak pṛthak svapnaḥ iva
translated: And they see the various categories of things imagined by their own ignorance, each separately, like in a dream.

original: vyāvahārikā anye jīvā anyena na jñāyante /
analyzed: vyāvahārikāḥ anye jīvāḥ anyena na jñāyante
translated: Other empirical individual souls are not known by another.

analyzed: svena dṛśyāḥ jīvāḥ tu svāpna vat prātibhāsikāḥ eva iti etat pakṣa sāraḥ
translated: But the individual souls that are seen by one's own are only apparent, like in a dream. This is the essence of the position.

original: atra cānyaṃ jīvaṃ tadguṇadoṣādi vā vyāvahārikamanyo jīvastathābhūto na jānāti cettarhi
analyzed: atra ca anyam jīvam tad guṇa doṣa ādi vā vyāvahārikam anyaḥ jīvaḥ tathābhūtaḥ na jānāti ced tarhi
translated: And here, if another individual soul or its qualities, faults, etc. are not known by another in that way, then

analyzed: tad samāgama ādi prasaṅga abhāvāt saha anubhūtayā eka sādhyaḥ lokavyavahāraḥ katham
translated: how is the continuous worldly usage, which is accomplished by a single experience along with that,

analyzed: nirvartyeta iti arthaḥ
translated: performed? This is the meaning.

analyzed: sva avidyā kalpitam eva paśyanti iti uktyā para vārttā anabhijña tvam vyāvahārika jīva antara vṛtta anabhijña tvam sidhyati
translated: By the statement that they see only what is imagined by their own ignorance, it is established that they are unaware of the affairs of others and unaware of the affairs of other empirical individual souls.

analyzed: na hi te jīva antara avidyā kalpitāḥ
translated: For they are not imagined by the ignorance of other individual souls.

analyzed: kintu mūlāvidyā kalpitāḥ eva
translated: But they are imagined only by the root ignorance.

analyzed: lokavyavahāraḥ pi prātibhāsikaḥ evā iti ced tarhi eka jīva vāda unmeṣaḥ
translated: If it is said that worldly usage is also only apparent, then the doctrine of a single individual soul is implied.

original: tatra ca doṣa ukta eveti hārdam // // //
analyzed: tatra ca doṣaḥ uktaḥ eva iti hārdam
translated: And the fault stated there is in the heart.

analyzed: kiñca svayaṃprakāśa tva vibhu tva eka tva nitya tāḥ
translated: Moreover, self-luminosity, omnipresence, oneness, and eternality,

original: tvadabhyupetā bādheran saṃvidaste 'dvitīyatām // //🔽saṃvinmātre 'vidyākalpito meyamātṛbheda iti paramataṃ vistareṇa pratikṣiptametāvatā /
analyzed: tvad abhyupetāḥ bādheran saṃvidaḥ te dvitīya tām  saṃvid mātre vidyā kalpitaḥ meya mātṛ bhedaḥ iti para matam vistareṇa pratikṣiptam etāvatā
translated: which are accepted by you, would contradict the non-duality of consciousness.🔽So far, the view of others that the distinction between object and subject is superimposed by ignorance on mere consciousness has been refuted in detail.

analyzed: atha saṃvidi para abhimatam nirviśeṣa tvam pratikṣipati kiñca ityādinā
translated: Now, with the words Moreover... and so on, he refutes the view of others that consciousness is without distinctions.

analyzed: te iti asya agre matām iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder of those is views.

original: bhavadabhimataireva dharmaiḥ saviśeṣatvaṃ saṃvidaḥ prasajyata iti bhāvaḥ // //
analyzed: bhavat abhimataiḥ eva dharmaiḥ sa viśeṣa tvam saṃvidaḥ prasajyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that consciousness is implied to have distinctions by the very qualities accepted by you.

analyzed: saṃvid eva na te dharmāḥ
translated: Those are not the qualities of consciousness itself.

analyzed: siddhāyām api saṃvidi  vivāda darśanāt teṣu
translated: Even when consciousness is established,🔽the dispute is seen to be about them.

analyzed: tad rūpāṇām ca bhedataḥ
translated: And because of the distinction between their forms.

original: svarūpābhedātteṣāṃ na saṃvidaḥ sadharmatvamiti śaṅkāmanūdya nirācaṣṭesaṃvideveti /
analyzed: svarūpa abhedāt teṣām na saṃvidaḥ sadharma tvam iti śaṅkām anūdya nirācaṣṭe saṃvid eva iti
translated: Anticipating the doubt that those are not the qualities of consciousness because of the non-distinction of their forms, he refutes it by saying consciousness itself...🔽Even when the nature of consciousness is agreed upon, the Buddhists, Naiyāyikas, Mīmāṃsakas, and others dispute

analyzed: sampratipanne saṃvid svarūpe tad nitya tva vibhu tva eka tva sva prakāśa tva ādau bauddha naiyāyika mīmāṃsaka ādīnām
translated: about its eternality, omnipresence, oneness, self-luminosity, and so on.

original: vivādāt svarūpabhedācca teṣāṃ dharmāṇāṃ saṃvitto na saṃpratipannasaṃvidabhinnatvaṃ
analyzed: vivādāt sva rūpa bhedāt ca teṣām dharmāṇām saṃvittaḥ na saṃpratipanna saṃvid abhinna tvam
translated: The cognition of those dharmas is not accepted to be non-different from the cognition of the self, due to the difference in their nature and because of dispute.

analyzed: teṣām yujyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is not proper.

analyzed: svarūpa bhedaḥ ca ātmasiddhau nirūpitaḥ nusandheyaḥ
translated: And the difference in nature should be understood as explained in the proof of the self.

analyzed: na ca te bhrānti siddhāḥ te yena advaita avirodhinaḥ
translated: And they are not established by error, by which they are not contradictory to non-duality.

analyzed: tattva āvedaka vedānta vākya siddhāḥ hi te guṇāḥ
translated: For those qualities are established by the Vedanta statements that reveal reality.

original: nanvevamapi teṣāmaparamārthatvātparamārthadvitīyarāhityaṃ surakṣitameveti cettatrāhana ca te iti /
analyzed: nanu evam api teṣām aparamārtha tvāt paramārtha dvitīya rāhityam su rakṣitam eva iti ced tatra āha na ca te iti
translated: If it is argued that even so, their non-duality with the ultimate reality is well-protected because they are not the ultimate reality, then it is said And they are not...

original: tavāpi tattvedamparaśrutyantasiddhāste dharmāssaṃvido nityatvādaya ityeva matam /
analyzed: tava api tattva idam para śruti anta siddhāḥ te dharmāḥ saṃvidaḥ nitya tva ādayaḥ iti eva matam
translated: It is your view also that those qualities of consciousness such as eternality are established by the other Vedanta statements that reveal reality.

analyzed: tat taiḥ sa viśeṣa tvam durvāram
translated: Therefore, the existence of distinctions with them is unavoidable.

original: teṣāṃ bādhe tulyanayena saṃvido 'pi bādhaḥ syāditi dyotyate tattvāvedaketyādinā // //
analyzed: teṣām bādhe tulya nayena saṃvidaḥ api bādhaḥ syāt iti dyotyate tattva āvedaka ityādinā
translated: It is indicated by tattvāvedaka etc. that if they are negated, consciousness would also be negated by the same reasoning.

analyzed: ānanda sva prakāśa tva nitya tva mahima ādi atha
translated: Just as bliss, self-luminosity, eternality, greatness etc.

analyzed: brahma svarūpam eva iṣṭam
translated: Are accepted as the nature of Brahman itself.

analyzed: tatra api idam vivicyatām
translated: Let this be examined there also.

analyzed: brahma svarūpa abhedasya eva tad dharmeṣu para abhimata tvāt tatra prākāra antareṇa api dūṣaṇam āha ānanda iti
translated: Since the non-difference of Brahman's nature is itself accepted by them as its attributes, he states the refutation in another way: In bliss, etc.

analyzed: ānanda śabdaḥ bhāva pradhānaḥ
translated: The word ānanda (bliss) is predominant in the sense of existence.

analyzed: mahima a vibhu tvam
translated: Mahī (greatness) is omnipresence.

analyzed: ādi padāt eka tva ādi grāhyam
translated: The word ādi (etc.) should be taken to include oneness and so on.

analyzed: atha iti yadi arthakam
translated: Atha (if) means if it is so.

analyzed: avyayānām aneka artha tvāt
translated: Because indeclinables have multiple meanings.

analyzed: brahma iti yāvat nirdiṣṭam tanmātram kim sukha ādayaḥ
translated: Up to Brahman is indicated, is that mere bliss, etc.?

analyzed: athavā tasya te
translated: Or are they of that?

analyzed: yat vā te eva brahma saṃjñinaḥ
translated: Or are they themselves designated as Brahman?

analyzed: vikalpayati paramatam brahma iti iti
translated: He considers the opponent's view: Brahman, etc.

analyzed: kim ānanda tva ādayaḥ brahma svarūpa mātram
translated: Is the nature of Brahman mere bliss, etc.?

analyzed: uta tad niṣṭhāḥ dharmāḥ
translated: Or are they attributes of that?

analyzed: āhosvit teṣām eva pratyekam brahma saṃjñā
translated: Or are they themselves individually designated as Brahman?

analyzed: samuditānām vā iti vikalpaḥ  ādye tad tad pada āmnāna vaiyarthyam veda lokayoḥ  pūrva ukta nītyā abhedaḥ ca
translated: Or of the combined ones? This is the option.🔽In the first case, the mention of each word is useless, and there is non-difference according to the previously stated method.

analyzed: jagat janma ādikāraṇam
translated: And it is the cause of the creation, etc. of the world.

analyzed: abhyupetya eva hi brahma vivādāḥ teṣu vādinām
translated: For the disputants argue about Brahman only by accepting it.

analyzed: dvitīye sā eva taiḥ eva brahmaṇaḥ sa dvitīya tā
translated: In the second case, by them alone there is duality of Brahman.

analyzed: ādye iti
translated: In the first case.

original: atyantābhede 'natiriktārthakatvātānando brahma satyaṃ jñānamanantaṃ brahmetyādau sahapāṭhasyānarthakyaṃ prasajyate /
analyzed: atyanta abhede n atirikta arthaka tvāt ānandaḥ brahma satyam jñānam anantam brahma ityādau saha pāṭhasya ānarthakyam prasajyate
translated: In the case of absolute non-difference, since there would be no additional meaning, the simultaneous mention in passages like Bliss is Brahman, Brahman is truth, knowledge, and infinite, etc. would be meaningless.

original: na hi ghaṭaḥ kalaśa iti sahapāṭhaḥ /
analyzed: na hi ghaṭaḥ kalaśaḥ iti sahapāṭhaḥ
translated: For there is no simultaneous mention like A pot is a water-pot.

analyzed: brahma svarūpa aikya asambhavam ca teṣu dharmeṣu smārayati pūrva ukta iti
translated: And it reminds us of the impossibility of oneness in nature among those attributes, saying as stated before.

original: dvitīye kalpe tu brahmaṇaḥ saviśeṣatvaprasaṅga ityāhadvitīyaiti /
analyzed: dvitīye kalpe tu brahmaṇaḥ sa viśeṣa tva prasaṅgaḥ iti āha dvitīya eti
translated: But in the second alternative, Brahman would be liable to have distinctions. He says In the second, etc.

analyzed: sā eva bhavat abhimata viruddhā eva
translated: That itself is contrary to what is accepted by you.

analyzed: tṛtīye brahma bhidyeta tanmātra tvāt pade pade
translated: In the third, Brahman would be divided, because of being mere that at every step.

analyzed: tad samūhaḥ brahma taru vṛnda vana ādi vat
translated: Or Brahman is a collection of those, like a forest is of a multitude of trees, etc.

original: tṛtīye pratyekasamudāyakoṭyoḥ pratyekakoṭiṃ dūṣayatitṛtīye iti /🔽pratyekaśo brahmatvamityatra nānā brahma prasajyate satyaṃ brahma /
analyzed: tṛtīye pratyeka samudāya koṭyoḥ pratyeka koṭim dūṣayati tṛtīye iti  pratyekaśaḥ brahmatvam iti atra nānā brahma prasajyate satyam brahma
translated: In the third, he refutes the individual and collective alternatives, saying In the third, etc.

analyzed: jñānam brahma  anantam brahma
translated: Here, Brahman being individual, many Brahmans would result, like Satya Brahman, Knowledge Brahman,🔽Infinite Brahman,

analyzed: ānandaḥ brahma iti
translated: Bliss is Brahman.

analyzed: khaṇḍaḥ muṇḍaḥ pūrṇa śṛṅgaḥ gauḥ iti atra iva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is like in Khanda, Mundha, Pūrṇaśṛṅga, Gaura.

analyzed: tanmātra tvāt tad tanmātra svarūpa tvāt brahmaṇaḥ
translated: Because of being mere that, because of Brahman being the nature of mere that.

analyzed: satya tva ādi samudāyaḥ brahma iti atra doṣam āha tad samūhaḥ eti
translated: He states the fault in the statement that the aggregate of truth etc. is Brahman:

analyzed: vināśa vat iti mudritaḥ pāṭhaḥ śuddhaḥ
translated: The printed reading as if perishable is incorrect.

analyzed: taru vṛndasya vana tva vatsatya ādi samudāyasya brahmatve
translated: If the aggregate of truth etc. is Brahman, like the forest being of the collection of trees,

analyzed: samudāyasya samudāyi ananyatve pratyeka pakṣa ukta dūṣaṇa anativṛttiḥ
translated: if the aggregate is not different from the components, the objections stated for each component are not overcome.

original: atiriktatve sāṃśatvaṃ guṇatvaṃ ca prasajyate brahmaṇa iti bhāvaḥ // //
analyzed: atirikta tve sāṃśatvam guṇatvam ca prasajyate brahmaṇaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: If it is different, Brahman is subject to having parts and being a quality. This is the idea.

analyzed: prakarṣaḥ ca prakāśaḥ ca bhinnau eva arka vartinau
translated: The highest and the light are indeed different in the sun.

original: tena na kvāpi vākyārtho vibhāgo 'sti nidarśanam // //
analyzed: tena na kvāpi vākya arthaḥ vibhāgaḥ sti nidarśanam
translated: Therefore, there is no example anywhere of the division of the meaning of a sentence.

analyzed: nanu satya ādi vākyam akhaṇḍa artha param svarūpa lakṣaṇa vākya tvāt
translated: But the sentence about truth etc. has an indivisible meaning, because it is a defining sentence about the nature [of Brahman].

analyzed: divā divi prakṛṣṭa prakāśaḥ sūryaḥ
translated: The sun is the highest light in the day and in the sky.

analyzed: niśi ca tathābhūtaḥ candraḥ iti vat iti nirviśeṣa brahma siddhiḥ iti atra āha prakarṣaḥ ca iti
translated: And the moon is of that nature at night. Thus, Brahman is established as without distinctions. In this [the opponent says]: The highest and the light etc.

analyzed: dṛṣṭāntaḥ pi na kevala ravi ādi svarūpa mātra paraḥ
translated: The example also is not merely about the nature of the sun etc. alone.

original: kintu ravyādivyapadeśagocarārthasyāsādhāraṇākārapradarśanapara iti nirviśeṣādvaitarūpo 'khaṇḍaḥ samānādhikaraṇavākyārtho nidarśanabhūto naivāstītibhāvaḥ
analyzed: kintu ravi ādi vyapadeśa gocara arthasya asādhāraṇa ākāra pradarśana paraḥ iti nirviśeṣa advaita rūpaḥ khaṇḍaḥ samāna adhikaraṇa vākya arthaḥ nidarśana bhūtaḥ na eva asti iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But the meaning of the statement of the sun etc. is to show the uncommon form, so the undivided meaning of the sentence, which is the form of non-dual without distinctions, is not found anywhere as an example.

analyzed: kvāpi kvacid api samāna adhikaraṇa vākye
translated: In some sentence that is co-extensive.

analyzed: avibhāgaḥ akhaṇḍaḥ
translated: Undivided, undivided.

analyzed: jāḍya duḥkha ādi apohena yadi ekatra eva vartitā
translated: If it exists only in one thing by excluding dullness, suffering, etc.,

analyzed: jñāna ānanda ādi śabdānām na sataḥ sa dvitīya tā
translated: then the words knowledge, bliss, etc. do not have a second that is real.

analyzed: atra śaṅkate paraḥ jāḍya iti
translated: Here the opponent raises an objection with the word dullness.

analyzed: jñāna ādi padam na jñāna tva ādi viśeṣam pratipādayati
translated: The word knowledge does not denote the particularity called knowledge.

analyzed: kintu jaḍa tva ādi apoham eva
translated: But it denotes only the exclusion of dullness.

analyzed: apohaḥ tu vyāvṛttiḥ abhāvaḥ dhikaraṇa svarūpam eva iti na brahmaṇaḥ sa viśeṣa tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And exclusion is a negation, the form of the substratum itself, so there is no contingence of Brahman having distinctions.

analyzed: jaḍa ādi tad tad padārtha pratiyogika vyāvṛtti svarūpa tva bodhanena ca arthavat tā padānām iti śaṅkituḥ āśayaḥ
translated: And the words have meaning by conveying the nature of exclusion which is the opposite of each thing like the dull etc. This is the intention of the objector.

analyzed: na iti atas pūrvam atas ca iti yojyam
translated: The reply is No, because of the previous argument etc. should be supplied.

analyzed: parapakṣa anuvādakaḥ ślokaḥ yam  apohāḥ kim na santi eva
translated: This verse is a restatement of the opponent's view.🔽Are exclusions non-existent?

analyzed: santaḥ vā
translated: Or are they existent?

analyzed: na ubhaye pi vā
translated: Or neither.

original: sattve satsadvitīyaṃ syāt jaḍādyātmakatetare tā pare // //
analyzed: sattve sat sa dvitīyam syāt jaḍa ādi ātmaka tā itare pare
translated: If existent, it would be with the second existent. The other would be of the nature of inertness, etc.

analyzed: atra vikalpya doṣam āha apohāḥ iti
translated: Here, considering the fault, he says Apohas.

original: nobhayena santo nāpyasantaḥ /🔽sadasadvilakṣaṇā iti yāvat /🔽apohānāṃ sattve doṣamāhasattve iti /
analyzed: na ubhayena santaḥ na api asantaḥ  sat asat vilakṣaṇāḥ iti yāvat  apohānām sattve doṣam āha sattve iti
translated: They are not existent by both, nor are they non-existent.🔽Up to different from existent and non-existent.🔽Regarding the existence of Apohas, he says If existent.

original: apohānāṃ sattve taiḥ sataḥ sadvitīyatā syādityarthaḥ /
analyzed: apohānām sattve taiḥ sataḥ sa dvitīya tā syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: If Apohas exist, then what is existent would be with the second existent, is the meaning.

analyzed: asattve dūṣaṇam jaḍa ādi ātmakā iti
translated: The fault in non-existence is stated by of the nature of inertness, etc..

analyzed: jāḍya ādi apohānām abhāve jāḍya ādi prasaṅgaḥ iti yāvat
translated: Up to if there is no Apoha of inertness, etc., there would be the contingence of inertness, etc..

analyzed: sattva sat sa dvitīyaḥ svāt jaḍa ādi ātmaka tā itare iti
translated: If existent, with the second existent, of the nature of inertness, etc., the other.

analyzed: mudrita pāṭhaḥ śuddhaḥ
translated: The printed text is impure.

analyzed: sat asat vyatireka uktiḥ pūrvam eva parākṛtā
translated: The statement of difference from existent and non-existent has already been refuted.

original: tathātve ca ghaṭādibhyo brahmāpi na viśiṣyate // //
analyzed: tathātve ca ghaṭa ādibhyaḥ brahmā api na viśiṣyate
translated: And if so, Brahman is not distinguished from pots, etc.

analyzed: tṛtīyam pratikṣipati sat asat iti  sat vyatireke sattvam
translated: He rejects the third by If so.🔽If different from existent, it is non-existent.

original: asadvyatireke ca sattvaṃ vyavasthitamiti sadasadbhinnatvaṃ kasyāpi na sambhavatīti pūrvamevoktamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: asat vyatireke ca sattvam vyavasthitam iti sat asat bhinna tvam kasya api na sambhavati iti pūrvam eva uktam iti arthaḥ
translated: And if different from non-existent, it is existent. Thus, the fact of being different from existent and non-existent is not possible for anything, it has already been stated, is the meaning.

analyzed: dūṣaṇa antaram āha tathātve iti
translated: He states another fault by If so.

original: apohānāṃ brahmasvarūpatve sadasadvilakṣaṇatve ca brahmaṇaḥ sadasadvilakṣaṇatvaṃ prasajyate prapañcasyeveti bhāvaḥ // //
analyzed: apohānām brahma svarūpa tve sat asat vilakṣaṇa tve ca brahmaṇaḥ sat asat vilakṣaṇa tvam prasajyate prapañcasya iva iti bhāvaḥ  /
translated: The idea is that if Apohas are of the nature of Brahman, and Brahman is different from existent and non-existent, then Brahman would be subject to difference, like the world.

analyzed: kiñca apohya jaḍa tva ādi viruddha artha asamarpaṇe
translated: Moreover, in not conveying the mutually contradictory meanings of the negatee, such as inertness, etc.,

analyzed: na eva tat tat apohyeta tad eka arthaiḥ padaiḥ iva
translated: it cannot be negated by words having the same meaning, as if they were negating inertness, etc.

analyzed: dūṣaṇa antaram āha kiñca iti
translated: And he states another objection: Moreover, etc.

original: jaḍādivyāvartakadharmabodhanamantarā jaḍādivyāvṛttirna pratipādayituṃ śakyate satyādipadairjaḍādiparyāyapadairiveti vyāvartakadharmabodhakatvamavarjanīyam
analyzed: jaḍa ādi vyāvartaka dharma bodhanam antarā jaḍa ādi vyāvṛttiḥ na pratipādayitum śakyate satya ādi padaiḥ jaḍa ādi paryāya padaiḥ iva iti vyāvartaka dharma bodhaka tvam avarjanīyam
translated: Without conveying the quality that distinguishes from the inert, etc., the exclusion from the inert, etc. cannot be conveyed, as if the words sat, etc. were synonyms of inert, etc. Thus, the quality that distinguishes is unavoidable.

analyzed: tathā ca taiḥ dharmaiḥ saviśeṣa tvam brahmaṇaḥ durvāram iti arthaḥ
translated: And thus, it is the meaning that the qualified nature of Brahman is irresistible by those qualities.
That and that inertness, etc.

analyzed: apohyeta vyāvartyeta  /
translated: should be negated, i.e. excluded.

analyzed: pratiyogini dṛśye tu yā bhāva antara mātra dhīḥ
translated: But when the counter-correlate is seen, the mere cognition of another entity

analyzed: sā eva abhāvaḥ iti iha api sadbhiḥ te sa dvitīya tā
translated: is itself non-existence. Thus, even here, for you, there is duality with existence.

analyzed: iti sa viśeṣa tva upapādanena saṃvidaḥ nirviśeṣa tva nirasanam
translated: Thus, by establishing the qualified nature, the non-existence of the non-qualified nature of consciousness is refuted.

analyzed: nanu vyāvartaka dharmavat tvam na bodhyate
translated: But the possession of the quality that distinguishes is not to be conveyed.

analyzed: kintu jaḍa ādi vyāvṛtti rūpatvam eva bodhyate jñāna ādi padaiḥ brahmaṇaḥ
translated: But it is only the nature of Brahman as distinguished from the insentient etc. that is denoted by the words 'knowledge' etc.

analyzed: tat na jaḍa tva ādi prasaṅge iti ced tatra āha pratiyoginī iti
translated: If it be said that there is no possibility of Brahman being insentient etc., he says 'the counter-correlate' etc.

analyzed: yogye pratiyogini anupalabhyamāne dhikaraṇa mātra jñānam eva tad abhāvaḥ iti jñāna viśeṣa rūpa tvāt abhāvasya
translated: When a suitable counter-correlate is not perceived, the mere knowledge of the substratum itself is that non-existence. Thus, non-existence being of the nature of a particular kind of knowledge,

analyzed: jñāna viśeṣa rūpaiḥ satya ādi pada lakṣya arthaiḥ abhāvaiḥ bhāva rūpaiḥ sa viśeṣa tā brahmaṇaḥ
translated: Brahman is involved in having particularities by means of negations which are the objects denoted by the words 'existence' etc. which are of the nature of particular kinds of knowledge,

analyzed: prasajyate iti arthaḥ
translated: and by means of existences. This is the meaning.

analyzed: abhāvasya jñāna viśeṣa rūpa tvam iti mata viśeṣeṇa idam
translated: This is said with regard to the particular opinion that non-existence is of the nature of a particular kind of knowledge.

analyzed: yat vā bhāva antara mātra dhīḥ iti upalabhyamānam bhāva antaram iti arthe paryavasannam
translated: Or, the mere cognition of another existence comes down to the meaning of 'the perceived other existence'.

analyzed: yogye pratiyogini anupalabhyamāne tatra adhikaraṇe yat bhāva antaram upalabhyate tat eva
translated: When a suitable counter-correlate is not perceived, that other existence which is perceived in that substratum is itself

analyzed: pratiyogi vyapekṣayā abhāva vyapadeśa bhāj iti adhikaraṇa vṛtti dharma antara rūpa tvāt abhāvānām
translated: the part that is designated as non-existence in relation to the counter-correlate. Thus, since negations are of the nature of other properties that occur in the substratum,

analyzed: taiḥ sa viśeṣa tvam prasajyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: the implication is that Brahman is involved in having particularities by means of them.

analyzed: dvavye bhāvaḥ dharma rūpaḥ
translated: Non-existence is of the nature of a property in a substance.

analyzed: dharmasya tu sva para nirvāhaka tvena svarūpam eva abhāvaḥ
translated: But the nature of dharma itself is non-existence, as it fulfills one's own and others' purposes.

original: sati sambhave dharmāntaraṃ veti yathopalambhaṃ vyavasthā /
analyzed: sati sambhave dharma antaram vā iti yathopalambham vyavasthā
translated: If possible, it is another dharma. The determination is according to the perception.

analyzed: yasmin pratīyamāne itara āropaḥ na ghaṭate
translated: In that which is cognized, the superimposition of another does not occur.

analyzed: tasya eva tad abhāva rūpa tvam
translated: That alone has the nature of its non-existence.

original: satsvarūpe pratīyamāna eva bhedānāmadhyāsācca tatra tasyaiva netarābhāvarūpatvaṃ sambhavi /🔽na cāvidyayāviśadaṃ bhāsamāne sati bhedabhramaḥ /
analyzed: sat svarūpe pratīyamāne eva bhedānām adhyāsāt ca tatra tasya eva na itara abhāva rūpa tvam sambhavi  na ca avidyayā a viśadam bhāsamāne sati bheda bhramaḥ
translated: Even when the existent nature is cognized, and the superimposition of differences occurs, therefore, the nature of that alone is not possible as non-existence of the other.🔽And when the indistinctly appearing existent is superimposed as different, there is delusion of difference.

original: avidyānivṛtau viśadaṃ bhāsamāne tu na sa iti viśadasvarūpasyābhāvarūpatvaṃ sambhavatīti vācyam /
analyzed: avidyā nivṛtau viśadam bhāsamāne tu na saḥ iti viśada svarūpasya abhāva rūpa tvam sambhavati iti vācyam
translated: But when the distinctly appearing existent is superimposed as different, there is no delusion of difference. Therefore, the distinct nature is possible as non-existence. This is not to be said.

original: vaiśadyasya svarūpatve pūrvamapyavidyādibhedāropāyogāt /🔽svarūpātiriktatve tu tasyaivābhāvarūpatvaṃ na svarūpasyeti prasaṅgāt /
analyzed: vaiśadyasya sva rūpa tve pūrvam api avidyā ādi bheda āropa ayogāt  svarūpa atirikta tve tu tasya eva abhāva rūpatvam na svarūpasya iti prasaṅgāt
translated: Because, if distinctness is the nature, then even before, the superimposition of difference by ignorance etc. is not possible.🔽But if it is distinct from the nature, then that alone has the nature of non-existence, not the nature. This is to be said due to the logical consequence.

original: kiñca nirviśeṣe svaprakāśe vastuni viśādāviśadabhānameva durvacam /
analyzed: kiñca nirviśeṣe sva prakāśe vastuni viśāda āviśat a bhānam eva durvacam
translated: Moreover, in a self-luminous object without distinctions, the indistinct and distinct appearance is indeed inexpressible.

analyzed: sa viśeṣe tu katipaya ākāreṇa bhānam aviśadam
translated: But in one with distinctions, the appearance in some form is indistinct.

analyzed: sarva ākāra bhānam viśadam iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: The appearance in all forms is distinct. This is the distinction.

analyzed: kiñca brahmaṇaḥ dravya tve sadharmaka tvam
translated: Moreover, if Brahman is a substance, it has properties.

analyzed: adravya tve tu kasyacid dharma rūpa tvam prasajyate
translated: But if it is not a substance, it follows that it has the form of some property.

analyzed: dravya adravya vilakṣaṇa tvam tu na sambhavi ityādikam anusandheyam atra
translated: But being different from substance and non-substance is not possible. Such things should be understood here.

analyzed: iha api iti apinā satya ādi padānām apoha lakṣaṇāyām api na nirviśeṣa tva siddhiḥ
translated: Here also, by the word api (even), it is shown that even if the words sat (true) etc. have the nature of exclusion, the establishment of being without distinctions is not possible.

analyzed: lakṣaṇā kalpanā āyāsaḥ eva iti dyotyate
translated: It is shown that there is only the effort of assuming a secondary meaning.

analyzed: evam apoha rūpāṇām api satya tva ādīnām sat asat anirvacanīya tvam nirastam  bhūta bhautika bhedānām sat asat vyatireki tā
translated: In the same way, the indescribability of the true etc. which have the form of exclusions, as being neither existent nor non-existent, is also refuted.

original: kuto 'vasīyate kiṃ nu pratyakṣāderutāgamāt // //🔽pratyakṣādīni mānāni svasvamarthaṃ yathāyatham /
analyzed: kutas vasīyate kim nu pratyakṣa ādeḥ uta āgamāt  pratyakṣa ādīni mānāni sva svam artham yathāyatham
translated: How is the difference between the elements and their evolutes ascertained to be neither existent nor non-existent? Is it by perception etc. or by scripture?

analyzed: vyavacchindanti jāyante iti yā tā
translated: The means of knowledge such as perception etc. distinguish their respective objects as they are.

analyzed: vat sva sākṣikam  /
translated: This is the self-evident fact.

original: atha prapañcasyāpi prasaṅgātsadasadanirvacanīyatvaṃ paramataṃ nirasyati bhūte tyādinā /
analyzed: atha prapañcasya api prasaṅgāt sat asat anirvacanīya tvam para matam nirasyati bhūte tyādinā
translated: Now, in order to refute the opponent's view that even the world is neither existent nor non-existent, he says bhūte etc.

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādīni ti
translated: Perception etc.

original: svasvaprameyaṃ yathāyathaṃ tattadasādhāraṇākārato vijātīyasajātīyāntaravyattamavagamayanti pratyakṣādīnīti prasiddham /
analyzed: sva sva prameyam yathāyatham tad tad asādhāraṇa ākārataḥ vijātīya sajātīya antara vyattam avagamayanti pratyakṣa ādīni iti prasiddham
translated: It is well known that perception and other means of knowledge reveal their respective objects as distinguished from other heterogeneous and homogeneous objects by their specific characteristics.

analyzed: tad asādhāraṇa ākāreṇa sadbhāve eva vastūnām
translated: These means of knowledge establish the existence of things only by their specific characteristics.

analyzed: na tu sat asat anirvacanīya tve iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they do not establish the nature of things as existent, non-existent, or indescribable.

original: yathāgrataḥ sthite nīle nīlimānyakathā na / dhīḥ /
analyzed: yathā agratas sthite nīle nīlimānya kathā na dhīḥ
translated: Just as the cognition of blue in front is not the same as the cognition of blueness,

original: ekākārā / na hi tathā sphaṭike dhavake matiḥ // //
analyzed: eka ākārā na hi tathā sphaṭike dhavake matiḥ  /
translated: The cognition of crystal is not like that.

analyzed: kṣīre madhura dhīḥ yādṛś nā eva nibhba kaṣāya dhīḥ
translated: The cognition of sweetness in milk is not the same as the cognition of astringency in neem.

analyzed: vyāvahārāḥ ca niyatāḥ sarve laukika vaidikāḥ
translated: And all worldly and scriptural transactions are restricted.

analyzed: etat eva upapādayati yathā iti
translated: He explains this with the words 'just as' etc.

analyzed: nīle nīlamatiḥ
translated: The cognition of blue is of blue.

analyzed: sphaṭike dhavala matiḥ ca na eka viṣayā
translated: The cognition of crystal is also not of the same object.

analyzed: kintu paraspara vyāvṛtta guṇa viṣayā eva
translated: But it is only of qualities that are mutually exclusive.

analyzed: tathā kṣīre madhura dhīḥ
translated: Similarly, the cognition of sweetness is in milk.

analyzed: nimbe kaṣāya dhīḥ ca
translated: And the cognition of astringency is in neem.

analyzed: tathā ca artha bheda ālambana tvam jñānānām sthitam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus it is established that cognitions have different objects as their basis, this is the meaning.

analyzed: nīle nīla buddhiḥ eka ākārā eka viṣayā
translated: The cognition of blue is of blue, of one form, of one object.

analyzed: tatra nīle na nīla anya guṇa prasaṅgaḥ
translated: There, in the blue, there is no connection with the qualities of other things.

analyzed: dhavala matiḥ tu tatas bhidyate bhinna ākāra iti arthaḥ
translated: But the white-minded one is different from that, meaning having a different form.

analyzed: na eva iti asya agre tādṛś iti ākṣipyate
translated: The word not is implied before such here.

analyzed: na evam iti vā pāṭhaḥ syāt
translated: Or the reading could be naiva (not at all).

original: tattadvastvasādhāraṇākārabhede 'bādhitapratītimuktvā vyavahāramapi tādṛśamupanyasyati pramāṇatayā vyavahārā iti /
analyzed: tad tad vastu asādhāraṇa ākāra bhede bādhita pratītim uktvā vyavahāram api tādṛśam upanyasyati pramāṇa tayā vyavahārāḥ iti
translated: Having stated the unobstructed cognition of the existence of things in their respective uncommon forms, he also presents such usage as a means of valid knowledge, saying usages are means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: abādhita pratyakṣa ādi pramāṇa tad mūla vyavahāra balāt vastūnām tad tad asādhāraṇa ākāreṇa sattvam eva upeyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the existence of things should be accepted as being in their respective uncommon forms by the power of unobstructed perception etc. which are means of valid knowledge and the usage based on them.

original: satyaṃ pratītirastyasyā mūlaṃ nāstīti cenna tat /
analyzed: satyam pratītiḥ asti asyāḥ mūlam na asti iti ced na tat
translated: If it is said that although there is cognition of this, there is no basis for it, that is not so.

original: sā cedasti tasyā mūlaṃ kalpyatāṃ kāryabhūtayā // //
analyzed: sā ced asti tasyāḥ mūlam kalpyatām kārya bhūtayā
translated: If it exists, let its basis be imagined by the effect.

analyzed: śaṅkā atra anūdyate satyam iti
translated: The doubt is stated here with satyam (truly).

analyzed: pariharati na te diti
translated: He replies with na tat (that is not so).

analyzed: sāghu iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is saḥ (he).

analyzed: kārya balāt tad anuguṇam mūlam abādhita pratītīnām yathārthya vyavasthāpakam anumīyatām iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the basis which is in accordance with that should be inferred as the determiner of the truth of unobstructed cognitions by the power of the effect.

analyzed: kḷptam ca indriya liṅga ādi tad bhāva anuvidhānataḥ
translated: And the senses, inferential marks, etc. are established by their conformity with that.

analyzed: yaugapadya krama ayogāt vyavaccheda vidhānayoḥ
translated: Because exclusion and affirmation cannot occur simultaneously or successively.

original: aikyāyogācca bhedo na pratyakṣa iti yo bhramaḥ /
analyzed: aikya ayogāt ca bhedaḥ na pratyakṣaḥ iti yaḥ bhramaḥ
translated: And the error that difference is not perceived by perception because unity is not possible,

analyzed: bheda itaretara abhāva viveka agrahaṇena saḥ
translated: that is due to the non-apprehension of the distinction between difference and mutual absence.

original: aduṣṭendriyādereva mitiyāthārthye hetutvamanvayavyatirekasiddhaṃ nāpalapyaṃ cetyāha kḷpta miti /
analyzed: aduṣṭa indriya ādeḥ eva miti yāthārthye hetu tvam anvaya vyatireka siddham na apalapyam ca iti āha kḷptam iti
translated: And the fact that a non-defective sense organ etc. is the cause of valid cognition is established by positive and negative concomitance, and should not be denied, he says well-established.

original: vastubhedo nirduṣṭendriyarūpeṇa pratyakṣapramāṇenaiva gṛhyate iti yāvat /
analyzed: vastu bhedaḥ nirduṣṭa indriya rūpeṇa pratyakṣa pramāṇena eva gṛhyate iti yāvat
translated: It is only as much as the difference of entities is grasped by the means of valid cognition of perception itself in the form of a non-defective sense organ.

analyzed: atra śaṅkate yaugapadye ti  vyavacchedaḥ bheda grahaṇam
